content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Think "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of Dishonored and HP Lovecraft" in the form of a lightweight stealth/action/horror game with roguelike elements such as permadeath and procedurally generated voxel-based levels.  *Also, please don't judge the game by the tone of the preview video's energy and music.  It does not capture the feel of playing this game in the least.  Watch a video on youtube before making up your mind.  This game is generally slow-paced, a bit creepy, and involves a lot of meticulous exploration.Despite having roguelike elements and a more oldschool-gaming attitude, it's not terribly difficult if you're experienced at stealth games.  Hell of a lot of fun, creepy and unsettling, and each run will challenge you about the same as the last due to the random terrain/maze-like levels.  Do not be fooled by the ease of clearing the first world; the second world is by far the most hazardous!Simple gameplay with several ways to fight, a stealth system including the ability to "lose" a pursuer, and a "sneak attack" system for bonus damage.No cumbersome inventory management; simplified equipment system with a few upgrade slots, and a slot for 1 power/spell that can be changed easily.  High jump boots, lockpicking kits, magical amulet/token, etc.Voxel-based procedural world with nice atmospheric sound, music, and lighting.Great use of vertical space for levels overall and for each given floor, with lots of crawlspaces, hidey holes, ceilings, and cover to hide in. You can crawl, powerslide under low passages, sprint, or climb up ledges.You won't get hundreds of hours of gameplay out of this, but it's a great little game and has great potential if modders or the developers design additional levels to explore and enemies to fight.  And it stands on its own feet just fine.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												I really liked the atmosphere, but the games just to simple for me and lacked any depth.Played for a few hours to get the hang of it, then beat the game start to finish in little over an hour. You're never really rewarded, the combat doesn't require much skill, there are no bosses and theres very little variety amongst weapons and items.There are a total of 6 dungeons, 3 you have to collect orbs from to access the final dungeon. The only reward for completing the game is an orb to make the game more difficult.You mostly wander around looking for a hole to jump through to access the next floor on every floor until you collect the orb, then return to the library hub, start the next dungeon and repeat. The dagger and revolver are the main weapons you'll be using as the other few are not worth picking up.Guess it's okay if you get it on sale. Really wish it had more content to give it some diversity and it would of been exciting to fight a unique boss at the end of each dungeon. Don't really feel like there are any items in it that change the play style unfortunately, which inhibits replay imo.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												EDIT: Going back through my older reviews, I was a bit dissapointed in my past self for giving such a short and poorly explained review. Brevity does not equal quality, especially when the majority of your original review becomes your final paragraph on re-edit.Eldritch is a tense, dark, and interesting little game with a lot going for it. As one who grew up with Lovecraft's influences all around me, this seemed to be a dream come true. The added bonus of rogue elements cemented it as something I would love. As a staunch lover of Isaac and Teleglitch, I'm used to losing everythng. That fear of a run gone sour is always fresh in the back of my head, but that's often the motivation to jump back in for one more go. At the death of my first character, and the loss of every single key item needed to advance the story, I lost interest almost immediately after jumping in again and stopped not long after. Where did Eldritch go wrong?On a big scale, Eldritch couldn't be better for the gaming market. A voxelized rogue-like with horror elements and a semi-retro artstyle is basically a fusion of everything popular in the indie scene, and they still manage to make the look all their own.Where the problems emerge is from the very hook; roguelike elements. The gameplay is simple and a bit charming and silly to boot, yet with no stats or leveling, there is nothing for you to improve over time. Of the two weapons in the base game outside of your fists are a knife and a revolver. No more, no less. No upgrades, nor perks. To counter this, there are about 6 magic spells to use with their advantages and disadvantages. Some are useless, while others completely broken in their power. There is some equipment that you can find or buy too, but only a few are worth picking up, but there being about 10 in total makes it easy to find what you want quickly. Money, bullets and keys are your collectables. You can throw rocks and bottles. That's it. Randomization can't change much when you're going to see the same things regardless.This, sadly, also applies to areas as well. Everything looks the same, and always ends up more or less in the same spot. Different geometry, yes, but once you see it once, you've seen it all. The enemy A.I. is overall mindless as well. Save for the Weeping Angel-esque statues which may make you♥♥♥♥♥♥yourself first time through, everything follows a simple routine of chase you til you're either too far away or dead. The minecraft elements are fun but make it much easier to circumnavigate trap rooms and such. Once you understand the core game, the threat is minimal, and the game grows dull.This would be easily forgivable if death didn't obliterate your progress, demanding you do the exact same things in nearly the exact same areas with nearly the exact same challenges, destroying any willpower I had to see it through. Apparently, the ending is a dissapointing text message, so I'm pretty sure I didn't miss much.Eldritch suffers from an identity crisis. The areas are wonderfully fun the first time through, but there is very little to offer on multiple playthroughs. Whereas Isaac had a wealth of items and combinations to urge you on, and teleglitch entire world shifts with each run, Eldritch sits at a very indecisive middle, with too little of each to justify extended play, and the great parts spread so thin and far with padding, it highlights just how short a game this would be if it didn't wipe all your progress. Good for a weekend if you want something different and it's on the cheap, but ultimately not at all worth full price.

												"Eldritch" is a strange case for me, as I am not a huge fan of dungeon crawlers. But this one intrigued me, being the fan of Lovecraftian works as I am. The randomly generated dungeons offer a huge replay factor, as does the New Game Plus feature once you complete the man story. Posted: December 1, 2015
												Recommended. The game has its flaws, but they are overshadowed by its successes.Before I begin, you should know that I do not play many first-person shooters, and almost no horror games to speak of. Eldritch is not a "horrror" game per se, but seeks to encourage a similar atmosphere and as such was a newer experience to me than it might be for many others.Eldritch is a strange combination of Lovecraftian horror and first-person-shooter that somehow managed to blend its disparate elements together very well. Anything with a Lovecraftian atmosphere should attempt to mimic the tone and atmosphere of its inspiration - the entire point of which was to make the reader feel not only helpless and hopeless, but utterly insignificant. First-person-shooters, on the far end of the spectrum, are most often about empowering the player to often absurd levels, though recently the trend has been to take a more 'realistic' disempowering approach.If you're willing to jump into the game with your eyes closed - which is easy, as the trailer gives off the entirely wrong atmosphere - the game can begin as very disempowering, and even very unsettling. The use of FOV, lighting, background noise and uncanny help to establish a horror setting early, but still leave the player plenty of room to maneuver.The feeling of uneasiness is sadly fleeting for most of the game, however. Once you learn how the stealth system works and how the enemy AI reacts, most of the game is actually fairly easy. The "eldritch abominations" usually die with a few whacks from a knife or shots from a pistol, and an easily-locatable backpack item lets you revive as many times as you have enough artifacts (in-game currency) to afford.Towards the end of the game, presuming you have the presence of mind to find the three special (useless) equipment items, the tone shifts toward disempowerment again. Some enemies will either be very strong or downright invincible, and once you're no longer able to slip past them like a whisper or revive yourself after death, the feeling of uneasiness returns as you realize that it will only take a few mistakes to end the game. Usually, that is not a terrible consequence, but because dying in Eldritch results in having to start over from the beginning, it (often) means losing hours of progress. This was a good design choice, I think, because it makes the closing of the game difficult and forces the player to adopt extra caution in their movements. This game is not the strongest example of first-person-shooting, exploration, Lovecraftian horror or even unease-inducing atmosphere on Steam. But it does each job well enough to blend into something interesting and, to my eyes at least, unique.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Eldritch is one of those games that strip out all of the fat and leave only interesting and fun interactions. This is pure, organic gameplay from start to finish, and that's why I love this game.Eldritch randomly generates levels by compositing premade rooms in a 4x4x3 3d matrix. Most rooms have little nooks and crannies to explore, and the effect on gameplay by one environmental set piece is affected by adjacent rooms. What you end up with is a 3d labyrinth that forms an interesting level on every single playthrough. In my opinion, this method of level generation is superior to alternative methods used in Delver or Tower of Guns.Stealth is simple yet effective and intuitive in Eldritch. You can lean around corners and crouch to lower your profile and avoid making noise. Attacks on unaware enemies deal more damage, and you can augment your stealth with silent boots, the cloack power, or even the teleport power. (A la Dishonored) In later levels and new game plus, you will need to have mastered stealth to survive.Not every enemy can be defeated in Eldritch. Shoggoths can not be fought; you must run away. (This can cause moments of terror that remind me of Amnesia.) Similarly, you will encounter wraiths which always revive after a couple of seconds and "weeping angel"-like lizard statues that can only be killed with dynamite. (Just don't wake the statues.) In addition to that, new game plus makes direct combat with many enemies a bad proposition, so you may want to stealth around even the killable enemies.Because of the block based world, the environment is destructable. You can blow a hole through a wall or floor with dynamite or by use of the destruction amulet. In addition to that, there are tools that increase your vertical mobility and ways to circumvent locks. All of this leads to a Deus-Ex like system where every situation has multiple solutions.Eldritch features permadeath, which I believe is necessary for this game to work. Every time you play the game, you get a new level. You can not memorize a level and go back and try again. The fact that you can't fall back on memory means you must always rely on your skill and wits.You are limited to two weapon slots. This is a weakness in the game, since you will probably want to stick with the pistol and dagger for most situations. There are also very few weapons availabe, which limits gameplay variety.While I personally prefer equipment based systems over standard RPG progression, one should take note that you may get all the powerups you need in the first world.There is an upcoming expansion coming, and information released by the developer suggests there will be more items and weapons when that comes. I will likely update my review at that time.In short, Eldritch is an amazing and highly interactive gem of a game. This is a game that tests your ability to think as much as your ability to shoot, and fans of immersive sims will be satisfied with the variety of interesting and well designed interactions that Eldritch has to offer.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												A fun first-person rogue-like that uses voxel-based environments. Game mechanics are simple and easy to learn and you will likely encounter 80%+ of the items in the game within the first half hour. The game can be beaten in only a few hours but the procedural generation of the levels makes replayability fairly high. This helps keep gameplay from being too repetitive, along with the fact that many items can used in multiple ways and there are a variety of spells you can learn as the game progresses. There is a quality stealth aspect to the game as well. Enemies can be alerted to your presence by sight or sound and you can crouch to minimize your footsteps. You can also throw items/use spells to distract enemies. Overall it's a very unique game that is worth picking up on sale.

												I remember receiving this in a humble bundle package and finding it to be a bit disappointing in terms of its rogue-like  repetitive level design. For H.P Lovecraft fans, this would be an adequate fanfic adaptation of some of his lore with a unique rogue premise. Enemies can be punishing as they are fascinating. There are numerous enemies and environments to justify the purchase of this game, it's just that they can become more of the same rather quickly, and there's no real concept of story. Just levels inspired by the lore of Lovecraft's books. If I didn't get this for next to nothing, I wouldn't have went out of my way to get it. But the enemies, weapon choice, and nifty environments make it a worthwhile way to kill an hour or two.

Posted: May 8, 2014
												A while ago I did a pretty "meh" review of this game, so I've decided to roll back my sleeves and do a good old fashioned pros and cons list.PROS-Lovecraftian monsters are really great because fans of the Cthulhu Mythos get a fun chance to pull out their spotter's guides and get to work. -Glorious replayability. Just glorious.-Decently difficult, it will take you a few tries to beat the game, and even I have not beat the game to get the special ending.-Challenge for speedrunner-Spell system which functions similarly to the spell system from dishonored or whatever those things are called from Bioshock (Sorry, have not played Bioshock in a while).-Its a roguelike... What more do I have to say?-Good amount of rooms to expore in randomly generated levels.-2 campaigns, a special halloween level, a New Game+ mode, and the Arkham Asylum. No not that one.CONS-A few monsters are just reskinned.-All free sounds, so if that bugs you, I don't know, go into the files or something.-No co-op multiplayer.Alright, now time for the ratings!Story: 6/10 It is okay, but mostly just a backdrop for the gameplay, which is alright in this kind of gameGameplay: 10/10 This is where the game really shines, and it shows that a lot of work was put into it. I mean you can slide around if you crouch while running. Its amazing.Replayability: 8/10 It can get somewhat repetitive, but is still amazing.Atmosphere: 6/10 I'm a little torn on this one. The sunken city of Ryleh was not exactly up to my standards of Lovecraftian horror, but some bits are quite nice. Not that great though.Total: 75 This game is very good and I love it to pieces. I would honestly rate it as one of my all-time favorite games. WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? BUY IT.

Posted: March 17, 2015
												World 1: I scoffed, I shrugged, I triumphed.World 2: I hid, I ran, I cowered.Eldritch, very brazenly the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of Minecraft and Spelunky, bides its time, initially presenting itself as easy and cartoonish and a shameless coattail-rider, before blossoming into a sort of oddball terror . A simple setup, exploring a dimension that’s in equal parts Lovecraft and Minecraft – CraftCraft, then – and accessed from portals in an occult library, yields randomly-generated, peril-packed levels in the current post-roguelike fashion.It’s hard to get past the Minecraft thing, naturally, and there is a part of me which bristles at the apparent attention-seeking nature of it but it doesn’t at all play the same way.I’ve been quite enjoying this game and so has anyone i've shown this game to,i would definantly recommend picking this one up.

Posted: January 6, 2014
												I'll be frank about it, it is fun to play but some gameplay aspects could have been handled better.First of all, you can't choose the difficulty level until you finish a complete run of the game. The game mechanics are pretty easy to learn so, depending on your experience as a gamer, you may feel a sense of unsatisfaction from the lack of challange the game initially presents (this is what irked me at first). Things really get better when you unlock the higher difficulty.The dungeons in the game are each composed of 3 floors, each floor is composed of 16 room blocks on a 4x4 grid. The dungeon structure is randomized, but the room blocks are presets and after a while it gets a little repetitive, though it keeps things simpler.The game offers stealth gameplay, equipment to make your character capable of certain feats like higher jumps or higher speed, magic spells, a little set of balanced weapons and permadeath, which is always nice in these games. It also supports a substantial number of languages and has basic video/audio option settings (and a FOV slider! yay!).Not for everyone's taste but, if you're into it, it will keep you entertained.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												As a massive fan of H.P. Lovecraft I can whole-heartedly recommend this game. As a massive fan of rogue-likes, as well, I can recommend this game. Eldritch delivers a simple objective: escape the confines of a cursed library by collecting the three hidden souls of famous Lovecraft beings. Good luck getting to them, though: this game is tough.The controls are straightforward: you can run, you can crouch, you can punch, and you can use items and spells. Items include weapons ranging from rocks and knives to pistols and wire trap guns. Spells grant you the ability to open locked doors, hide yourself, or charm enemies. The occasional piece of gear also grants you the ability to run silently or disregard fall damage. These items are important because they're your best bet for getting out alive.The core elements of Eldritch are executed very well: survive the ever-changing dungeons of Lovecraftian horror by sneaking and/or fighting your way past a multitude of cultists, lizardmen, shoggoths, and other UNNAMEABLE horrors (thumbs up if you get that reference.) Every floor is fraught with tension and peril as the atmospheric music and groans of the otherworldly follow you wherever you go. Considering the game gives an achievement for beating it in under 10 minutes or less, it's pretty cool to know this game is actually really short, but also really hard. I died more times than I count, but I never felt cheated. Overall, I say this game is definitely worth a buy. It isn't a scary or horrifying game, but it has atmosphere in spades and it's a fun take on the classic Lovecraft formula. The always shifting and changing dungeons fit the source material very well. Yog-Sothoth would agree: this game is cool.

Posted: February 22, 2015
												Eldritch is a really nice little game. The gameplay is fluent and there are some creepylooking monsters to kill. But I have two little complaints for the game. Firstly I wish there are more weapons, I get it that you only have one arm to use them, so shotguns and machine guns are out, but I would have at least liked a flare gun or another pistol. Secondly the enemey respawns can get annoying sometimes. But I definiteley recommend this game (I later found out that you can stop them from respawning by simply not looting their corpses)The graphic may scare possible players off but because of the game´s pixelated look runs smooth like butter. Also worth a mention is the game´s soundtrack, it´s just great, really atmospheric and it sets the mood perfectly. The randomly generated levels are a blast to play, I personally really liked the second book and the mountains of madness free DLC area. These levels often include a nice gimmick, for example tiles that crumble when you step on them or invicible enemies. The levels often end with a special building, that really looks quite impressing and stands out from all the randomly generated stuff you have seen throughout the level.Speaking of randomly generated, this feature works surprisingly well. I have never seen any weird constructions during my playthrough and the game still has a feel of leveldesign even though it actually shouldn´t be there.To sum it up I would definiteley recommend this game. It took me about 20 hours to get through the whole game (visiting every area and dying sometimes) and nearly every minute was great and tense fun!Also the game includes one of the best snow levels I have played in a long while ;)(for a more serious take on the Lovecraftian mythos you should check out the long forgotten "Shadow of the comet" and "Prisoner of ice" and the more popular "Dark corners of the earth")

Posted: December 18, 2014
												Based somewhat loosely on the writing of H.P. Lovecraft, Eldritch is a fairly easy "roguelite" with emphasis squarely on the "lite". The story, like much of Lovecraft's pulpy output, is paper thin (I'm a fan, but he was very inconsistent). You're trapped in some kind of magical library and you have to collect certain artifacts to close a portal and save the world from monsters. Elder-gods, I suppose. It doesn't really matter, to be honest. Apart from the occasional paragraph or two of flavour text, there's no real narrative. The game has you descend through three seperate dungeons to collect the "Souls" of various powerful creatures, though they aren't bosses and you won't see them represented in the game. These dungeons are loosely themed as a cave, a sandy temple, and a poisonous jungle. Whenever you collect a soul you can return to the library and open a new book; a new dungeon to explore. These stay open even if you die, so once you've unlocked them all you can attempt them in any order you like, though as the first dungeon is so easy it's a great place to stock up on useful items and is the sensible one to do first. You can, if you like, dash through the mazelike levels and just head for the stairs down ignoring any items and enemies along the way, but sometimes you'll have to take a circuitous route. That is, unless you make your own path. Yep, levels are destructible, meaning you can use dynamite to simply explode a path to your goal. Great fun.With its vivid colour palette and chunky voxel graphics, evocative of minecraft, Eldritch looks fairly cutesy and gentle, but this belies a genuine creepyness. Admittedly, this is barely apparent in the first dungeon, which is so easy that you can simply sprint around it, running circles around the enemies and laughing in their silly, fishy faces. There is one enemy here, a shoggoth, whose thick gurgling and grotesque alien appearance should give you cause for concern. Now, stealth seems a better option, and as you're crouched in a corner peering into the murk as the heaving blob hunts for you, vulnerability and fear creep up on you. The shoggoth will have softened you up, but it's the game's second dungeon that really shakes things up and definitely stands out as the one most deserving of respect. You might want to tread carefully around those curious, croc faced statues; they aren't so innocuous as they appear. And watch out for the softly moving wraith, which can't be dispatched by mortal means. There are enemies that are common to all dungeons, like the shuffling, sighing cultits (sounding not unlike Grandad pottering about the house in his slippers) or bad-tempered bugs which seem to fight with anything they encounter. They'll seem like old friends, now. Eldritch has finally got its claws out, and they're sharper than they look. In truth, the lack of variety in Eldritch means that it will be only a few hours before you're used to the tricks and tracks laid out in the various dungeons, and you'll be back to sprinting confidently from room to room. In four hours, I've beaten the game and a longer optional dungeon, and it's fairly telling that there's an achievement for speedrunning the game in under ten minutes. It isn't a long game, but it is quite charming and easy to get into. It's a shame that often, the fear comes less from the atmosphere than from a run ending prematurely, meaning having to start over. If there were a bit more variety, it would soften the blow, but if you can get Eldritch for a few quid, you'll not feel hard done.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I want to be clear here; I really, REALLY enjoy this game. The atmosphere is great, the art style is interesting, the gameplay is fairly fun and the Lovecraftian source material is just tops. The maps are pretty interesting while changing just enough in their layout to feel different from one another. Weapons are fairly interesting, with the more powerful ax or pickax being much slower than the quicker knife. There's also a sort of tactical choice in the spells and items you can carry.Do you want to be sneaky? You'll want Stealth boots and melee weapons, as guns will alert enemies nearby to your presence. Want to avoid combat as much as possible and be able to make quick getaways? You'll want to probably be carrying either a bundle of TNT or a Grappling Hook with you so that you can either quickly climb to safety or make your own escape route by blowing a hole in the nearest surface. Maybe you'll want to equip the Teleport or Lift to get away fast over big ledges. There are quite a few options here.  While this game is great fun as a dungeon crawl, I do have a serious problem with one of the mechanics, and that is the fact that you lose literally everything you have accrued save for any money you've put in your bank chest and any new level you opened. This poses a serious problem.Throughout the time you character remains alive, you gain more hit points by drinking from fountains, can stock up on ammunition for the revolvers, find spells at idol statues, and, most importantly, find the souls of the Old Ones needed to escape the library hub of the game.However, when your character lives, you lose literally everything they're carrying; any spell you may have, additional hit points are reduced back to the starting 3, all ammunition, any artifacts (money) you have on your person, all of your gear includeing weaponry, AND any Old One souls you may have found and placed on the three altars to escape the library? Yeah, they're back at the end of a now newly randomized zone. There is a way to revive yourself, if you're carrying a First Aid Kit, but that costs 50 artifacts to use. I suppose unless it disappears (I didn't notice if it was still in my inventory after the one time I was able to use it) that 50 Artifacts to not lose everything is a fairly good deal.I don't usually take issue with punishment via losing precious items. Games such as Minecraft have made me very familiar with this mechanic, but the issue is that in Minecraft you can store items and the enemies are at a constant level of difficulty, while in Eldritch, the enemies are stronger in each new zone.There is a sneaking mechanic in Eldritch, and if you can find the Stealth Boots and snag them from a merchant (honestly, who would blow all those artifacts?) you can even sprint without enemies hearing a single footstep, but with the randomized terrain and the fact the enemies actually wander the map it's eventually going to be inevitable that you have to square off against something, and if you've just died and are trying to enter the Mountains of Madness, or are fighting a Snakeman with nothing but your bare fists and three hit points, it becomes more or less a necessity to have to slog all the way through the beginning area again, which is now completely re-randomized, and you are forced to re-collect Dagon's soul.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Eldritch is a First-Person Roguelike, a sub-genre that seems to be growing rather large and unwieldy at times when people want to call it a Roguelike-like or Roguelite, based on the short stories and novellas of H.P. Lovecraft and as you might can guess such an idea very well sounds like a wet dream for many horror readers, myself included.Luckily it works out, Eldritch is a very well executed and fun Roguelike-like-lite-whatever that blends in elements from procedurally generated worlds to mix well with the horrific atmosphere one tends to expect when it comes to Lovecraft. You start in a library that you are stuck in and three mystic books that transport you to other worlds, Dagon, Nyarlathotep, and R'lyeh, your objective is to reach the end of each world to get the three souls needed to unlock the door and escape from the library.Much like other Roguelikes you start with low hitpoints, little to no equipment, and when you die you lose everything except for any money you deposit into the bank, with your one life you must gather money, keys, ammo, and equipment, and find fountains to add more hitpoints or statues to give you magic powers, all the while dodging Fishmen, Cultist, Shoggoths, and other eldritch horrors.The controls and gameplay are very well done, combat is done with relative ease, you can stealth past enemies or sneak attack them, knives for up close attack, rocks to throw, bottles to smash onto walls to lure enemies away, guns can be found though with scarce ammo and sometimes you can find dynamite that will let you blow open parts of the level, most of these items as well as keys to open locked doors can be found in the world, but some can also be bought for money by finding a shopkeeper, this also goes for equipment such as Jump Boots and Good Luck Charms.Most of the story is told through books you find laying around, and overall despite the great atmosphere, the plot lacks quite a bit and the endings are nothing to write home about, but in the grand scheme of things it is a minor complaint to an amazing game.Overall this game is well worth playing, though a bit lacking in content, for the price and fun you will have playing it and exploring the very Lovecraftian world it builds, I fully recommend buying this game.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												At first glance, Eldritch appears to be a cheap minecraft clone, but what you actually get is a much more fufilling experience. It's a rather charming little game that doesn't try to be anything that it isn't, but at the same time it is also a very intriguing adventure through several levels and labyrinths that become more challenging (or less, depending on the power-ups you find) as you progress through the game. It is not a long game by any means, nor is it too complex, but what it lacks in complexity it makes up for with it's sheer curiousity; You have absolutely no idea what to expect from this game. In short, this game was very pleasant to play through and I definitely recommend this little gem.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												This game is Fantastic! It's a randomly generated dungeon crawler with some really cool things going for it. Every fight you get in is terrifying, due to your low health and Weapon mechanics (stronger the weapon, harder to find ammo it is). Once you unlock a level it's permanantly unlocked, though every time you die you lose everything (including the items you get for beating a level). PRACTICE MAKES PERFECT IN THIS GAME. You will farm money, you will die to the same enemy type over and over (looking at you lizard statues), and you will get frustrated, but you will have more fun than any full priced game i've bought in recent memory. GET IT NOW. Only thing that could make it better would be coop play. *Crosses Fingers*

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game is a lot of fun.  It's a rogue-like game with procedurally generated levels and fully destructible environments, and it pulls this combination off very well.  You can blast holes through walls, sneak around and explore, and defend yourself against enemies very well in the environments it produces.  I feel like I've mastered the base game, but the NewGame+ mode and Mountains of Madness expansion still beat me senseless, and I'm loving the challenge.I really enjoyed the stealth aspect, and combat is simple but very fluid.  You can sneak behind an enemy, peek around the corner, leap out and stab the unlucky fishman.  Now rush to the next place of safety while his buddy furiously attacks.  Fun times.  :D  This game avoids the regular trappings of holding a button to hug a wall or other gimmicky stealth methods -- it's very approachable, and remains effective as you master it.  I never felt like the controls were inhibiting my ability to sneak or fight effectively.There's a variety of strategies, including sneaking, sprinting, keeping to high ground, and so on.  Your limited item set increases the challenge, yet still gives you a wide variety of tools and options.  Do I want a destruction amulet to burrow through walls, or a compass to find my way?  Which spell do I want most -- conjure blocks or cloaking?  Do I need the medkit, or tinning kit?This is not so much an "ooga-booga-booga" scary game, but it can build to a very tense and even creepy atmosphere, particularly after you complete the first book.  It ranges from being funny, to tense, to action-packed, and even freaky.I recommend it to fans of stealth and rogue-likes in particular.

												If you like cute games, I heartily recommend Eldritch.  It's a Lovecraftian first person sneaker/roguelike with Minecraft aesthetic.  The shoggoths are particularly kawaii.  Fans of Thief will be immediately at home as this game has Q/E leaning and edge mantling with the addition of sprint sliding!  There's no gaining levels or choosing a class or skills or anything - except finding a few weapons, equipment, keys, spells, health-up fountains and currency(artifacts).  The latter is the only thing that can be saved post permadeath in chests.  Best of luck giving those Elder Things the laugh.tl;dr version: Iä! Iä! Cthulhu Fhtagn! Ph'nglui Mglw'nafh Cthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn.

												I picked this up on the Halowe'en sale and can't say I recommend it.It has a strange ambiance to it that doesn't really feel of anything. Navigation is stressful, the graphics are ugly (and that's from someone who appreciates the charm of Minecraft's visual style), and combat is uninteresting. You can only carry two items at a time, which ends up just making me attached to rare things like dynamite, hoping to find a use for it.The game's only saving grace is the possibility that if I had played it more, I would have gotten into it - but I doubt it.I recommend this to people who like Lovecraftian-themed games, and don't mind the weirdly oversimplistic gameplay.It's hard to explain why - but this game just isn't my cup of tea.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Minecraft looking 3d first person rogue-like game set in lovecraftian mythos...There are some nice references and gameplay is interesting... You can try to outrun you adversaries or sneak past them... There are multiple items that can help you climb/destroy obstacles or enemies, but no real RPG elements...Atmosphere is really nice, and I found myself really scared in some moments...But... it does get boring fast... There is no real progress and original levels (without free DLC) are really easy... You'll probably finish them in an hour or so...So, what you are left with is free DLC level and constant trying to finish it... It is procedurally generated map but it gets familiar and you'll get bored fast...Verdict; I recommend it to the fans of Cthulhu mythos... To anyone else, there are better rogue-likes...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Eldritch is quite a lot of fun, though somewhat simplistic. There are not a huge amount of enemy types and tilesets, nor are there very many items. However, the levels are very well-generated and interesting, the monsters are creepy, and sneaking around the levels is a LOT of fun. Reviews have said over and over that the game is too easy, and I do concur that the actual act of attacking and killing enemies is typically challengeless as long as you remain unseen or strike quickly. In particular, the first book (level) is very easy. This is not always the case however; sneaking around avoiding combat is very important in the 2nd and 3rd books, and is very tense. I died quite a few times trying to complete the second book, but the third book was fairly easy overall. The end was exceptionally anti-climactic. I haven't tried the New Game Plus mode (unlocked after finishing the game, much harder), but I'm definitely going to give it a play-through (I rarely play a game again after finishing it, but I will with Eldritch, which says a lot).I would definitely recommend this game to fans of stealth games, those that like the retro blocky look, and Lovecraft fans (the Flying Polyps were particularly disturbing). Also, there's a free expansion coming out in a few weeks, we'll see what it adds.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												A rogue-like FPS inspired by the ouvre of H.P. Lovecraft, Eldritch is fun. It can be creepy, difficult, fast and furious - but overall, it's fun. The Minecraft-esque graphics are in no way an indication of gameplay, which can get quite intense, down in the dungeons with all those eldritch horrors (don't get me started on the stone lizards ...). The soundtrack's a little sparse (unlike the trailer), but it all adds up to a wonderful creepy feeling, where you're not sure if you should giggle or shriek. Definitely worth your time, especially if you're a fan or rogue-likes and/or Cthulhu.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Eldritch is about as much horror game as a horror-wuss like me can handle. It's basically Minecraft Cthulhu, a first-person dungeon crawler with blocky cartoony environments and monsters. The creepy evil of the Lovecraft mythos does come through, and there is definitely a survival element to the game.Your investigator character is not a superman. He/she is a normal person, with fairly limited health and ammunition. The monsters are not too bright, but they are legion, immortal and relentless. Should you slowly progress through a level, risking injury, death and getting trapped in order to stock up on more items? Should you race past the dangerous elite monsters, and risk facing a major baddie or trap later, under-leveled and empty-handed?The audio design, while initially cheesy (most of the monsters sound like the developer's buddy growling into a microphone), is quite effective at instilling a sense of danger. You will find yourself using your ears to judge where a monster is, how far away it is, and what it is. And you will have to make tough choices with that knowledge.As a newbie to the genre, I recommend this as a fun horror-lite first-person dungeon crawler. I suppose if you like concentrated terror and wearing brown pants, you could go play Amnesia or Alien: Isolation. But this is about as much creepiness as my britches can handle for now.One paranoid investigator's thumb up!

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												I'm a huge fan of metroidvania style games. I like a challenge. But games like Eldritch are damned annoying. If you die, you lose all progress except for any levels that you unlock and money that you've stored in the bank. Any cool items, spells, weapons or "experience" upgrades are lost. So you might as well start over each time that you die. Oh and good luck finding that sweet combination of items, weapons and spells again: everything is re-randomized upon death. I died a couple of times not because of the difficulty of the monsters, but because of typical accidents that occur in FPS games: one step too far and falling off a ledge, dying instantly, for example. Or mis-judging the range of a monster's hit-box. This game is brutally unforgiving and falls into the same old mis-placed nostalgic hard-on for "old school brutality" which was nothing but a shallow, cynical design by the developpers to get kids to spend more quarters. Not because of some mythical love of the gaming "craft". Pass on this if you have precious little time to waste. Get this game if you want to maintain your "old school" gaming cred.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
Product received for free
												Going back to the slightly simple graphics of classic games such as Wolfenstein 3D does not mean the quality of the game will drop. On the contrary, a lesser priority on graphics allows for more focus on gameplay. Eldritch gets the gameplay right, and even the simplified graphics suit the game, instead of looking dated.Eldritch is a difficult game, forcing you, the player, to maintain a constant vigil against anything that could deprive you of your meager health (3 hits, and you're down). Then you've got such difficult decisions to make such as do I take the gun, or the knife? Knife is melee, gun is ranged. Gun runs out of ammo, where the knife lasts forever. Now add in shrines to the forgotten Old Gods which grant you powers when you pray at them, angry penguins, fish people, and soul munching shoggoths, and you have Eldritch.I've not seen too much of the game, having repeatedly died in the first book (it'll make sense when you play the game, but think, level), but that's the nature of rogue-like games, and it does nothing to detract from the fun.Is it Steamified?Yes. Yes it is. Eldritch has both Steam achievements, and Steam trading cards. I have no idea how you'll get some of the achievements though, to my limited skills at least, they are all but impossible. Fun trying though.I received this game free, as part of the Steamified review program. For similar reviews and great giveaways please visit Steamified[www.steamified.com].

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												I've played for hours now and I still find it fun. I've completed these with 9 resurrects and countless Medical Kits revival. For spoiler reasons, there is an alternative ending.Once you have managed to finish a playthrough, there will be a orbm when you resurrect, for you to pick up to drastically increase the difficulty.Overall, this game has limitless replayability. The dungoens, items, and enemies are randomized every time you resurrect. All 4 dungoens has its own set of enemies and items. There are 3 levels per dungoen, and in each level there are 3 floors. Because of this, the game encourages the player to explore.The player has the ability to destroy and create blocks if they have visited the Destruction Amulet and the Materialisation Shrine. The player also have an option to use the dynamite to destroy walls and/or floors to create a new path. Eldritch also has some good stealth elements. It is up to the players to either go stealthy or just rush through the dungeons. But the more dungoen you enter, the more harder is it for you to escape without dying. Enemies will chase you until you are out of their sight for a few seconds.There is also a shopkeeper per level. Stealing, attemping to directly kill him or setting off the shopkeeper's dynamite, he will come after you. Shopkeepers are one of the most hardest to kill when the player enrages them.Albeit the game's lack of content, the equipable items and magic are enough to satisfy multiple aspects of Eldritch.

number of helpful: 14 of 28 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												When I first saw this on Steam Greenlight, I was both interested and skeptical. Interested because of the concept, and skeptical because it looked kinda meh. When it did have a Steam release, I decided to wait until it was on sale, and boy was it a mistake. Let me get the only good thing out of the way first. Eldritch has a wonderful concept. An FPS with rogue-like elements mixed in with some Lovecraftian lore sounds like a great idea. Scratch that, it IS a great idea. But sadly, as mentioned before, this is the only standout feature of the game, as the rest of the game is pure mediocrity. I would like to start off with the gameplay. You start off in a library, which is a base of operations of sorts. Here, you can take out or put in currency that you have obtained throughout the game, enter into levels (of which there are only three, plus that one level introduced in the free expansion pack), and cuztomize the look of your character (you can actually make yout character look like the god of rock and roll frontmen, Freddie Mercury, but this doesn't change the fact that the gameplay sucks). After you enter the level you wish to enter, you are put in a randomly made dungeon, and that is where the♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan. The game is so stupidly easy, and it feels like the game was designed for kiddies who have never played an FPS, as you can only wield two weapons at once, and you can only have one magic spell at a time. The AI isn't any better, as it is dumb as bricks. Currency in the game is used for two things, and that is to buy♥♥♥♥♥♥and to use magic spells, which is sadly the only other standout feature found in this game. The rogue elements are minimal. In fact, the only rogue part about the game are the randomized levels. Everything else is just look for the items and drink at wells to increase your HP. The FPS gameplay in the end feels generic and lame as ♥♥♥♥, and the rogue elements do not help to stir things up. Graphically, the game looks like♥♥♥♥♥♥ as it wants to look like an NES game, following that one ♥♥♥♥♥♥ trend in indie games that needs to ♥♥♥♥ing die. Now, you would think that because its graphics are♥♥♥♥♥♥ the framerate would be fine. Instead, you have some very noticable lag in windowed mode, and it is even more noticable in fullscreen mode. This shows that the game is poorly coded and has optimization issues. Overall, not worth your money. You would probably have more fun playing a full rogue-like game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Aesthetically the game owes a lot to Minecraft, which is reasonable when you consider you can blow apart walls/floors or create new ones with spells.  It didn't add anything to the game, but it didn't detract as much as I was worried it might.  The enemy models were still entertaining (I loved the fish people and the cthonians).  The sound design was well done, keeping things extremely tense, but still being necessary to know when someone was walking up behind you.  Gameplay-wise, it was somewhere in between true rogue-like and the kind of game I prefer where most of your advancement carries over between attempts.  Unlocked levels and artifacts carry over (or CAN carry over, in the case of artifacts, provided you found a chest to store them in before you die), though trying to jump into the later unlocked levels without the advancement from the earlier levels is foolish at best, so I found it better to just restart at the beginning anyway.  One thing I found interesting was that the strategy that ended up working for me was finding a shop in the first area that had a health pack (the only way in the game to get "continues") and, instead of trying to save up your artifacts to purchase it (since you'll need them to buy continues) just save up bullets until you have a dozen or so and kill the shopkeeper.  Then you can loot the health pack, maybe a luck amulet, and a pair of boots which will keep you going for the rest of the game.  The game isn't long, though I haven't played through the Mountains of Madness DLC.   There is a spell system in the game that I never even bothered with, since that spends artifacts and I was hoarding them for continues, though I do like that you get spells by praying to different elder gods.All in all it was an entertaining, tense, dungeon-crawly rogue-like with just a sprinkle of Lovecraft mythos on top.  No buyers remorse here.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												Eldritch lets you choose your pace most times, you can blitz around or stealth about.The allure of exploring the dungeons, getting health upgrades and buffing relics seemed like a bit of good fun.Within a few hours I've found he game has become tiresome, but for the wrong reasons.The enemies in the game are good, they vary and can prove to be a challenge.The exploring aspect first drew me in but I quickly saw the patterns and decided the rewards are not that great except for more max hp or ammo.It became a choir to search for these things.Also you are limited to only holding two weapons at a time.  This at first makes sense, but just becomes annoying later on.The only statue buff I found really worth it is the jumping one (mobility is a big thing in this game).The weapons are so-so but nothing I will remember- except for the TNT.  They are fun.My main gripe is the way the special 'you get the good ending' relics work, they do nothing but eventually take up 3 of 3 slots that normally grant additional buffs.I found by taking away these buffs the game is hurt as the player loses mobility and power, to me it made the difficulty feels artificial.When you die you lose the bonus hp you've collected, which is acceptable for a rogue like, but in this game it adds to the grind of searching to get it back up.The shops are ok but offer nothing you haven't already found.The pattern and repetition to the asylum was not for me.The aircraft ice level was fun at first but soon became highly annoying with falling stalactite.The humor and wit in the tailor is not in the game.Overall I feel like it was missing something, something that aids you to speed up the game or upgrades.. or just something, Alas due to the 'yes' or 'no' nature of steam, I would rather prefer to be in the middle for this one but side towards 'no'.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
												So imagine Minecraft as a randomly-generated dungeon crawler like Nethack, pitting you against the shambling horrors of the Cthulhu Mythos. That's pretty much Eldritch right there - and holy crap, is it fun. I may have to uninstall it until my class projects are done. (No prior knowledge of the Mythos is necessary!)Runs cleanly and fluidly even on lower-spec hardware, thought I'd have to draw the line on trying to play this on an Atom-CPU-powered netbook for example. Plays very smoothly on an i5 notebook with Intel's GPU.Anxious for Linux support and better STEAM integration (including cloud saves, achievements, and trading cards). Highly recommend!

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Eldritch looks like the developer wanted to take the spelunking from Minecraft and slap some Lovecraft on it.That sounds good enough for me to get the game, but sadly it doesn't live up to the expectations.The thing is, when you dig down in Minecraft, you don't know whether you're supposed to survive that. The caves aren't even made to be traversible, you could fall through a hole any time. You could hit lava, water or sand. The enemies aren't made to be killable/survivable with the most basic of equipment. If you take this out of the sandbox and make it a game on it's own, there's this implicit contract between game developer and player that says: "this is doable". This takes all of the tension away. This is something that should be apparent in the prototype stage of a game's production.Eldritch has easily traversible rooms which are "clean", compared to the messy world of MC. You can run so fast, that you don't even need to engage a single enemy. You can just run past to the exit (especially easy if you have a compass).There are so few items in the game, that I kept finding the same dagger and pistol over and over again. The dagger swings very rapidly and stunlocks enemies, so that there's really no need for other weapons.Most enemies die to a single hit. You can even throw the empty revolver at them and they keel over.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Full disclosure: I worked with this game's creator, David Pittman, back at 2K Marin.Eldritch is a first person roguelike-like with atmosphere and fiction inspired by the Cthulhu mythos, mechanics inspired by immersive sim games like Thief and Dishonored, and it's a really astute synthesis of those things.  Don't write it off just because it looks like a gloomy Minecraft in screenshots; Eldritch is full of tense, unique gameplay moments.  Can't wait for NEON STRUCT, Pittman's next game!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												So let me start off with a pros & cons list...-----PROS------Randomly generated worlds-Sneak mechanics in a randomly generated world is a nice twist-Surprisingly spooky & ambient-----CONS------Poor graphics that don't seem thematic, but lazy.-Very short, and with little replay value. (You can see that I've only played for 3.1 hours, more than enough time to beat the main campaign with absolutely no previous experience)-Enemies are all very, very similar. There seems to be about two different AI types, excluding the rock lizards and the slug thing. They pretty much either fly around or walk at you, and sometimes they shoot energy blasts. I got this game during a Humble Bundle, and was glad I didn't pay full price for it.  While I've oftentimes seen this game compared to spelunky, making that comparison is similar to comparing Minecraft and Terraria. Yes, there's mining and building and exploring, but that's about as far as you can draw the comparison. The biggest, most notable difference between Eldritch and Spelunky is the fact that this game is a roguelite, not a roguelike, like this game seems to advertise. Once you complete a world, the next area is permanently unlocked, with zero reason to visit earlier levels. You can also store the games currency at different parts of the level, to be withdrawn at a later time, or a later life. Another big complaint I have about this game is the fact that the graphics do not play to their strengths, much like many other indie games do. These graphics feel lazy, and oftentimes just make the game feel less professional. Yes, it's an indie game, but must indie games when confronted with graphic issues take a simple, more retro style and play to the strengths of that particular style. While the gameplay is solid, I don't feel like replaying the game. I don't feel like it has anything more to offer me than what I had experienced on my first playthrough. The game offers a New Game+ feature for those who beat it, but it feels slapped on, as if they just altered a few numbers in the code and called it good.This game is alright, but I don't reccomend it. If I still haven't swayed you, the only advice I can give to you is don't buy this game for anything over 50% of the full cost.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												If there's a rogue-like you have to buy, it's Eldritch. Based off the writings of H.P. Lovecraft, this game combines cute and creepy in the perfect manner. You have a variety of worlds to unlock and explore, with a very simplistic HUD and inventory system. That makes it easy to get into the game and start exploring. From throwing rocks to blasting with dynamite to a variety of magic spells to choose from, the player's bound to develop their own unique method of getting through the game. The library is where you start, and from there you can go to the Mountains of Madness, or explore the book-worlds of Dagon, Nyarlthotep, and R'lyeh. Each book-world has shops, traps, evil denizens, and quirks, all procedurally generated so no two journies are alike. If you wanna see a Cthulhi wearing a monocle or if you wanna punch a penguin to death, I would suggest this game before all others.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Tl;dr - Get this game! Eldritch is a wonderful mix between Dishonored's FPS Stealth gameplay and H.P Lovecraft's Eldritch Horror themes.You can play the game at a relaxed, stealthy pace to avoid damage or speed through levels in a test of skill.The visual style is basic, but effective in it's design. Enemies look unusual, otherworldly and disturbing.The soundtrack is fabulous, with an omnious ambient soundtrack and creepy sound effects to further immerse the player in horror.Content is fairly expansive, with three worlds spanning a total of 20 minutes - 1 hour to complete depending on your playstyle as the main questline. There is also a 'Mountain of Madness' Storyline and a time attack 'Asylum' mode.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												Elderitch is a game where you play a librarian who explores horrific temples/caves/libraries and traverses his/her way to the bottom of the level picking up various items. Its a roguelike, with randomly generated levels and permadeath. I only wish it could have done more. The base identity of Eldritch is good. A game with lovecraftian horrors, a stealth combat system, with innovative item choices. If someone described that game to me I would probably buy it. The monsters are scary (at first) with weeping angels and giant immortal shoggoths. The asthetics are nothing to write home about, but arn't bad either. Same with the soundtrack.However Eldritch doesn't do enough. Theres diffrent types of items, but only about 3 per item slot. Theres a stealth combat system, but it never expands on it. It has lovecraftian horrors, but since it's a roguelike, you get to see them a lot, and they become less horrific.With this alone, I could say that maybe you should buy the game on sale, and play through it then, if it wern't for one major issue.The game is just too damn easy. First, theres no boss fights. Which means the challenge of each 3 levels of a book (world) is the same. Second, the two items you can pick up in the very first level, the dagger and pistol, are enough to carry you through the entire game. In fact, only one other type of weapon shows up in the later books, and it sucks. Theres no reason to explore and test out new items, when there are two that are clearly the best. Speaking of item balance, the stealth boots take away any form of stealthy mechanic that the game tried to instill. It turns eldritch from a stealthy crawl into a dash up behind the monster and stab them.I beat the game in 3.4 hours. My final run was an hour long, meaning that it only took me two hours to figure out how to win.Spend your money on other roguelikes. Only buy this game on sale if you've already played all the good ones.TL;DRBuy this game if:You have already played all the good roguelikesYou REEEAAALY like lovecaftYou have trouble with most roguelike games, as they are too hard.DON'T buy this game if You want a challenge You like bossfights You enjoy the "new item" feeling that some roguelikes bring You are new to roguelikes

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												*This is entirely based on personal opinion but I think its worth sharing for a few people who might save their money.*I honestly like the themes and principles of this game quite a lot. It has unique and linear gameplay that still feels open-world and has consequences. The lovecraftian influence is a neat novelty, with interesting flavor.However:The game is very, very easy, relying mostly on grinding for supplies and unlocking powers and such. Most of all though, and this is entirely on me, I just find the Minecraft-homage graphics very ugly and distracting from the experience. A game meant to be so immersive and involved just loses all charm in faux 8-bit choppiness.To anyone this doesn't seem bad to, go for it! Neat ideas here. To those who agree with me, save your $15

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												This game seems like it tries to be too many things at once, and fails at all of them. Though eldritch aspects are clearly evoked (shoggoths, lizardmen, and other things with altogether too many eyes and tentacles and not enough pleasantness), the game inspires no cosmic horror, instead creating jump-scare horror at best. The graphics and design don't feel pleasantly nostalgic, they simply feel like the creators didn't try too terribly hard and just labeled it a "voxel" game to ride that trend. The controls and interface are not user-friendly, and the gameplay swiftly becomes dreadfully same-y.As it is a roguelike, of course, your gameplay experience will be a bit different every time you play. But my experience was not one which made me at all interested in playing the game more than the earnest try I gave it; you can look at a pile of rubbish from many different angles, but that won't change what it fundamentally is.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												If you're a fan of H.P. Lovecraft's mythos, or just enjoy some simple Roguelike exploration, Eldritch is 100% for you.  Four worlds as of the time of this review, each one based upon various stories and beings within the Cthulhu mythos (including the infamous Mountains of Madness), brought to you in a Minecraft-style first person perspective.  Randomly-generated procedural labyrinths, some rudimentary resource management, mystical powers, irritable shopkeepers, dungeon exploration, death traps, invincible Shoggoths...  it's all there, watching.  Waiting.Welcome to the Library.

I'll post it as an upvote for now, but I'm teetering on the edge, simply because of a few factors that are pretty noticable once you start playing for a while.The biggest factor being that it's too easy. Yes, sure, there's a new game plus, but the base game was so easy that I'm pretty sure that a new game plus wouldn't be too much harder to be honest.Another factor to consider is the length of the game. Had I not experimented with different features of this game and always played stealthily taking no chances, it's probably a three hour game at the very least.Now the good things about this game are that it has a stealth system, strikingly similar to that of Dishonored's. Dishonored was a great game to me; I replayed it many many times. So to have stealth similar to Dishonored's really made me ecstatic.I also like roguelikes, and this is definitely a roguelike. Although like I said before, it's a pretty easy roguelike, so it's not a "true" roguelike, if that makes sense.All in all, Eldritch IS a good game, but again, as I have said before, this game's VERY short and a little on the easy side. Definitely pick it up when it's on a sale.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												*This is entirely based on personal opinion but I think its worth sharing for a few people who might save their money.*I honestly like the themes and principles of this game quite a lot. It has unique and linear gameplay that still feels open-world and has consequences. The lovecraftian influence is a neat novelty, with interesting flavor.However:The game is very, very easy, relying mostly on grinding for supplies and unlocking powers and such. Most of all though, and this is entirely on me, I just find the Minecraft-homage graphics very ugly and distracting from the experience. A game meant to be so immersive and involved just loses all charm in faux 8-bit choppiness.To anyone this doesn't seem bad to, go for it! Neat ideas here. To those who agree with me, save your $15

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												This game seems like it tries to be too many things at once, and fails at all of them. Though eldritch aspects are clearly evoked (shoggoths, lizardmen, and other things with altogether too many eyes and tentacles and not enough pleasantness), the game inspires no cosmic horror, instead creating jump-scare horror at best. The graphics and design don't feel pleasantly nostalgic, they simply feel like the creators didn't try too terribly hard and just labeled it a "voxel" game to ride that trend. The controls and interface are not user-friendly, and the gameplay swiftly becomes dreadfully same-y.As it is a roguelike, of course, your gameplay experience will be a bit different every time you play. But my experience was not one which made me at all interested in playing the game more than the earnest try I gave it; you can look at a pile of rubbish from many different angles, but that won't change what it fundamentally is.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												There is something moving around on the other side of this wall. I can hear it shuffling and dripping some kind of unspeakable ichor as it slides over the ruined stonework. I have only my knife and a rock to keep me safe in this cyclopean hell and I must make it back to the relative safety of the labyrinthine library. A giggle rises from my lips, but I quickly silence myself. I cannot afford to lose my sanity in these deep corridors. I creep forward, darting my view in all directions. Suddenly, there is a dreadful noise behind me! I turn whilst steeling myself against this fresh horror… Awwww! It’s just the sweetest looking Deep One I’ve ever laid my eyes on! Come here, li’l guy! Come – OH GOD, WHY IS IT KILLING ME?Eldritch, by Minor Key Games, is a first-person roguelike set in a blocky Lovecraftian fantasy. It’s unforgiving of mistakes, and it’s so dang adorable, you’ll want to hug every deadly enemy you see. Next thing you know, you’re looking at the death screen, getting ready to resurrect back in the mysterious library.Like any good Lovecraftian horror, Eldritch begins with forbidden knowledge. You awaken in a library. Endless shelves of books, tables, and reading lamps surround you. The only exit requires the acquisition of three magical orbs to unlock. Reading one of three glowing books in the middle of the library will transport you to a deadly realm filled with traps and monsters. Your exploration of these three randomly generated dungeons will net you loot, weapons, and the orbs that will free you from imprisonment. Dying puts you back in the library. The catch? You have to gather the orbs in one life. If you die before you unlock the exit, you’ll lose any orbs you have returned to the library, forcing you to gather them again.The first dungeon you go into is easy. It’s baby’s first roguelike. You’ll be punching cultists, Deep Ones, and beetles to death. You’ll run through the halls with abandon. You’ll be given a magic spell by praying at a statue of Dagon and the artifacts that power your spell will litter the ground. You’ll find a revolver and you’ll never run out of bullets because looting the dead gives more ammo than you spent. The knife is god-tier. You’ll grab the first orb and you’ll teleport back to the library thinking, “This is it?” It’s a trap. In the second dungeon, you’ll run into deadlier monsters that will laugh at your ineffectual flailing. Your gun will never have enough bullets. The hissing Serpent Men will chase you. You’ll begin hoarding the increasingly scarce spell-powering artifacts. You’ll realize that the gameplay resembles Dishonored with its sneaking, spells, and assassinations. Just as you’re getting your groove again, a Shoggoth will crush you with it’s cuddly black tentacles. Awwww. You’ll wake up back in the library.That’s when the deeper mechanics of Eldritch start to make sense. There’s a lean button for a reason. Crouching makes you stealthier. Looting the enemies you kill makes them respawn somewhere else in the level. A rock can be the best ranged weapon because it’s quiet and you can recover the missile after you’ve thrown it. The knife is best used in sneak attacks from behind or above. Bottles can be thrown as a distraction. The Shoggoth will kill other denizens of the dungeon for you if you lead him into them. Spell-powering artifacts can be banked in a treasure chest so you don’t lose everything when you die. You’ll discover that you can purchase weapons and power-ups from oddball merchants. Do you want to keep your artifacts for spells, or spend them on boots that let you leap higher? You can unlock shortcuts to deeper dungeons, but zipping right to harder levels without getting some better equipment is a mistake. Finally, a Chthonian Worm will bite you to death with its lovable lamprey mouth. Awwww. You’ll wake up in the library again.The screen that informs you that you’ve died again has a button that lets you tweet the manner of your death to the world. It’s a painful reminder that Eldritch could really benefit from leaderboards or at least achievements to chronicle your struggles against the forces of cosmic terror. It’s hard to play any roguelike without a scoreboard after Spelunky’s wonderful daily challenges. No matter. Unlike Spelunky, most players will see the end before their hundredth death. Onwards! There are cute monsters to kill.This time, you’ll use the run-and-crouch move to slide through a hole as a Spawn of Cthulhu chases after you. This spell lets you teleport behind that Deep One and stick him in the back before the nearby cultist knows what happened. There’s the orb! If you can only reach it before the moaning horror catches up to you! Nope. You weren’t watching your step and the collapsing floor dropped you right next to your Shoggoth friend. Awwww. Back to the library with you.Recommended

												Very interesting game. Every level is split into 3 floors and every room can have some small building, so you really navigate in all 3 dimensions, and third dimension is used a lot. You often can sneak above the enemies, jump from one roof to another then fall down to stab someone from the back and then slide to a cover. Stealth system is good, fighting is simple, different magic spells, different items, everything is very cool. No stupid cutscenes or tons of dialogues.Also, you can throw a rock at the enemy, and it can ricochet back at you and deal damage to you! Totally awesome!

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												I was attracted by the Lovecraftian theme, but I was repelled by lack of save option. This game has something about it, but I guess that "something" is not my cup of tea. You learn this game by trial and error and exploration+memorisation is a large part of the game. There are few multi-level maps in this game. Your objective is to enter them, survive and find the exit. You accomplish this with 3 lives, keys, weapons or praying statues that you find throughout the map, while sneaking past the enemies or killing them (not all enemies can be killed, though). If you fail, you loose all your items and artefacts, resurrect and start again...and again...and again...and again. Get the idea?As I've said, not my cup of tea. No story either.7/10 for the concept. Thumb down for the difficulty.p.s. Although, if you're patient enough and learn the maps and tricks, the game becomes managable. That's the challenge.... and fun (for some people)! But it takes time.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												This game came out when "pixellated first person roguelike" was the genre du jour and every one man indie studio with dreams of becoming the next Phil Fish was tripping over themselves to throw one of these up on steam. It's kinda cool, and as a game it delivers the first person roguelike experience. However, first person roguelikes are not fun because first person roguelikes miss the entire point of the roguelike experience: turn-based gameplay that rewards strategy.The only enjoyable part of this game is the "derp" sounds the fish men make when they hear you in the distance.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												It's a great unique stealth fps with levels like you have never seen before.Don't buy it for those reasons:- It's only a light Roguelike, ie the difficulty isn't high, the randomization is just fair, don't buy it for this aspect.- It uses Lovecraft lore as thematic and there's some parts with a nice mood plus some interesting implementation of some monsters, but don't look for a Lovecraft game.But you could buy it for those reasons:- It is very fun from the fps stealth point of view, the stealth gameplay is quite intuitive and feels more natural than usual.- It has huge large levels with an extreme exploitation of heights as almost no fps made use at this level, one exception I know is the old fps Po'ed. That levels design would be enough to justify the use of sample graphics, to allow such large and complex levels inside descent production cost.- The levels have a fair randomization, but they have also an accurate tuned design for the exploration and progression point of view.- It offers a good range of tools to manage the levels in different ways.- Some monsters are quite unique, without to spoil anything, one really worth the quote, some statues you really need experiment in the game.Overall it's a game aimed to be relatively short but quite intense. The rogue-like aspect uses the fair randomization and helps increase the duration. It's a light fps stealth game with unique large levels exploiting intensively the heights, some parts succeed generate a rather good mood despite the low budget on graphics and sounds.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												No thanks. The game wasn't bad to start, learning some things about how the game worked, killing a few bad guys and praying to a few Old Ones. It wasn't flashy but it was somewhat enjoyable. I'd explored for about half an hour, no hint of a save point but that hadn't bothered me because I'd still yet to take any damage from the dozens of bad guys I'd encountered. I actually wondered if I had it on easy mode and if I should ramp up the difficulty. Then I a find a bad guy in a room....BOOM I put a bullet in his face. Follow it up with 4 more and still nothing. Then he spanks me with a one hit kill. I ressurect and have lost the gear I found so far. It felt cheap and it felt stupid. OK I learned that maybe that particular bad guy was to be feared but I wasn't going to drudge around a mediocre game to have more surprises like that thrown at me. Putting this one in the never-to-play-again pile.

Posted: December 6, 2016
												Fun at first until you realize all the flaws. You barely get any health so you have to watch your step at every turn which is a pain and then all the levels are random so you might not get any good weapons or anything and the only ways to upgrade is to find a shop somewhere in one of the levels or some other random thing you need to find and most of the time you can't get there before dying. There's not even any point trying to get upgrades or anything because once you die it's all gone, making it feel like you're making no progress at all. There's currency which you can use in the shops but it's pointless because when you die you lose it unless you store it in a safe box but then you need to take it out just to spend it so there's no point taking any out cause you'll probably die before using it. Also you pretty much can't beat the game at all unless you do it all in one session because there's some orbs you need to get and sure when you get them you unlock another level and that stays but the orbs you place on some pedastal which unlocks some door don't stay so you have to redo levels all over again anyway. Some of the enemies aren't fair at all like stone monsters that attack you when you aren't looking and they don't bloody die and some other monster that just doesn't die no matter how many times you knock it down so really this game is just a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥ Fine if you like replaying the same random levels over and over again but it's not for me.
