Posted: November 26, 2013
												Delicious. Put the shooter mechanics of Bioshock in a Spelunky-esque action roguelike, and mix with a Minecraft(ish) aesthetic. Oh, and there are Dishonored style magic powers, really smooth movement mechanics (dash and crouch to slide), solid stealth mechanics ... and enemies that are basically the Weeping Angels from Doctor Who. The game scratches a lot of itches for me :-)

Posted: June 7, 2014
												I really like this game. The dude who made this game knocked it out in a few months, then made the MoM expansion later, and that shows in the variety of gameplay shift from the early levels to MoM.This game is best played with a friend or two that you can switch off with on each level/death, on a big TV, with big picture and a controller. This is a horror game, but it isn't literally frightening like Nosferatu, it is just super tense and amusing. Go for it if you are a fan of action/stealth/exploration.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game is quite some fun, though it's not going to be for everyone. The story is pretty simple, wake up in library  with no memories and the only door locked with the keys in books that you must get through. While the gameplay is also simple the difficulty quickly works it's way up as you go through the the 3 books, with various challengs unique to each one. Once you get the keys you can leave, and you unock the new game plus mode which make the game much harder. The enmeies are quite varied and take plenty of unfluence from the love craftian side of horor. With basic cultists at the start, working you way all the way to unkown horrors that I really can't explain besides godzilla.This is a very caual rouge like. Death actaully means something, and dying means getting sent all the way to the start since there is no way to save besides starting at the point you left the game. If your looking for a nice game to play for a good 30 minutes or so, should definatley pick this up.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												When I first played Eldritch I was torn between hating the merciless permadeath features and absolutely loving the lovely (ish)voxel art and action-packed caving (sort of) then I forgot it and for a whileit lay dormant in my Steam Library, then it was rediscovered just as the Mountains of Madness free expansion was released. When I rebooted it and tried after a month I was surprised by how much more I understood about the mechanics and ways to defeat the enemies and in an half hour I had unlocked the second book! Overall I would say that if you don't mind dying over and over with no saves or item recovery, definately buy it.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												I enjoyed Edlritch as a small Pixel Dungeon game. The combat is instantly awarding in the beggining of the game as you scrounge around for ammo decide on if you are going to loot that corpse or pass to prevent them from respawning. (Enemies only respawn if you loot corpses.) There were a few disapointments though. Spending time on combo is simply not worth your time compared to how efficient it is to use a pick axe to just dig your way to the final room being able to skip past all of the enemies. *SPOILER ALER* If you spend any time in the libarray you will know that opening the libarray will allow the monsters of the dungeons to escape their prisonment meaning that after the first world you should skip to go for the 4th ice world and just dig your way to the end of the game, use a grapling hook to climb back up and juse use the path you digged out to reach the bottom of the dungeon to get back to the plane to fly off to the games ending. Any who if you get the game for a few bucks when it was on sale I would say that this game was well worth your cash but, if it's at full price just wait.

Posted: May 27, 2014
												 I have a particular interest in first-person realtime roguelike dungeon crawlers. If you've stuck around for that 8-word (or 5 combo-word) genre description, stick around for more because I'm gonna tell you what I think Eldritch does right and wrong by that genre.I want to sing some praises of the game.Character Control - Lean (left and right), crouch, slide (run/crouch), mantle (ledge climb).As simple as these four mechanics are, I feel they are essential for making a player feel like they are actually interacting with the environment instead of just... sliding through it with WSAD and jump alone. Third person action games are practically all Prince of Persia with the amount of climbing you do, but first-person games rarely attempt much. I appreciate Eldritch's effort here.Interesting Enemies - There are a couple that really force you to play differently, and one in a way that I had never seen in a game before. Others provide some fun flavor that's just enjoyable to interact with.Stealth - Most roguelikes don't feature any meaningful stealth mechanic. Thanks to the character control, Eldritch is very rewarding of careful, thoughtful advancement through its mazes. Since your character has little HP and healing is not terribly common, remaining in control of how you advance is essential to a sense of agency in a game that is otherwise random.Here are some Meh issues -Uninteresting Enemies - Most of the enemies have a boring fireball attack as their only offense. They are also highly predictable when pursuing you.Shops - Too sparse and expensive. The "bank" system which allows you store the game's currency from life to life isn't easy enough to access to make spending money worthwhile, which is a shame because some of the items really improve the experience.Length and Difficulty - After 5 hours and only 8 deaths, I beat Eldritch.  After you learn the enemy behavior, deaths only result from stupid mistakes or unlucky coincidences, so it doesn't give that broad sense of growth and education that good roguelikes have. The game also allows you to collect orbs to unlock "shortcuts" to the later dungeons (there are 3 to unlock), but to actually beat the game you have to collect all the orbs in a single life anyway. So the shortcuts are only practical for practice, not for actual progress. The result is that the length of the game feels artificial and tedious, rather than hard-earned and rewarding.The Ending - Getting to the end of a roguelike typically takes a lot of effort and it's nice to feel like your effort is tracked somewhere or you have some incentive to... do better or something. Eldritch says "you won and it's anticlimactic," in not so many words.Feature Light - The game feels a little hollow, probably as a result of lacking variety in the game mechanics, enemy, and level event variety. This makes me appreciate the control mechanics even more.Anyway, I'm glad I played Eldritch. It's made me aware of problems I'd have never considered for my own interest in the genre and it had its moments of excitement and inspiration.  I'll definitely continue to play Eldritch as they release more updates.

Posted: November 24, 2015
												Not Bad Not greatEldritch is a Rouge lite exploartion game set in a Lovecraftian world and done in a Voxel graphic style.  Think sillent hill if it was done in the minecraft engine.  You search several worlds inspired by the works of Lovecraft trying to decend or acend further into the level until you find the exit. along the way you'll encounter a number of monsters like, deep ones, mummies, shogotohs, flying polyops ect.The game is okay. they did a decent job of depicting a Lovecrafting atmosphere and your character is very weak leading to a real sense of danger. you feel small and helpless which is exactly how you should feel in a lovecraft game.saddly the voxel graphics take somthing away from the experince and theres only a handful of enemy types and only a couple are particularly intresting.  There a number of items and weapons you can get but these too are limited and most of them you'll ignore in faovor of more pratical things like the gun and dagger.  The rouge like nature of the game does add replayablity but greatly limits what can be done with the narrative which is somthing you don't want to skimp out on in a lovecraft game. If your a fan of Lovecraft this might be an intresting distraction for a bit but you'll likely grow bored of it quickly.  If your just looking for a strange indy horror game, there are worse games then this.  If your looking for a great story or a more dynamic game...i'd say get sillent hill or fatal frame.It was fun for awhile but i don't see myself replaying it anytime soon.

Posted: November 28, 2015
												A fantastic rouge-like styled after the classic horror novels by H.P. Lovecraft with difficulty only matched by its tense atmosphere and wonderful diversity in each play. It's by no means simple and you most certainly won't complete it in your first ten, twenty, fifty attempts! Heck, even with a huge statement like that I've only put a hearty 12+ hours into it so it's most certainly "learnable." It all relies on how quickly you can gracefully adapt to the game's changing environments... And I do mean gracefully. After mastering the game's controls (running, jumping, sliding, leaping and all that will be used quite frequently) you almost feel like you're being thrown around the map! On top of that you have a simple but hardly repetitive group of enemies to deal with ranging from fish-men to flying... organs? It's easy to conclude "well this is just impossible" but the game actually does have quite a few ways to completing it! Throwing yourself into the storm over and over won't do you much good so it's always good to take on a strategy. I've recently found stealthiness to be the ultimate path but you do have to be ready to lose some 35-50 minutes instantly from simple mistakes. If you don't feel like taking on all "three" worlds at once (it's difficult beyond comprehension but I've done it multiple times!) you can also try the Mountains of Madness: 10 levels of pure hell to retrieve your plane keys (keeping close to the books as always) and then heading all 10 levels back up to the surface! Fun alternative, right? Except.... Well, It's super tense and you'll get lost more than once as it begins to feel more like a labyrinth.  SPOILERS/TIPS A great way to start any campaign is by grabbing the compass from Dagon [The first world ] and returning to The Library. Next you'll probably want to do the Trick or Treat world [ the pumpkin in the bar area ] be prepared to spend about 2-5 minutes here gathering materials for your next run! After you've grabbed a grappling hook and a gun with over 15+ ammo, return to The Library and re-enter Dagon. Complete the first world as so:[for beginners]:-Always look for a way down and try not to re-enter previously entered rooms-Avoid looting dead bodies... and don't waste ammo on those that don't need to be killed!-Press Z to throw items (great if you need to drop your gun/grappling hook for a takeout punch)-Hold spacebar to lift yourself over ledges! It took me almost 8 hours to realize this... it'll save you keys and such, allow you into new rooms, and save you from getting stuck in holes-run and press C (the crouch button for sneaking) to do a power-slide! You'll look cool AND it'll make your jumps longer![For returning players]-Approach levels slowly! Pay attention to the map! Knowing your surroundings is almost necessary to escaping any level-If the opportunity to rush through a floor is available then you should most certainly take it; especially in later levels where there are tons of baddies chasing you down-don't hug walls unless you're sneaking; enemies can easily get the jump on you-try not to forget to peek around corners if you're uncertain how safe a room is (C+E/Q). You can shoot and cast spells when you're in this position-It took me nearly 70 attempts to complete the game and I have no doubt it'll take plenty less for you. Keep at it, soldier!

Posted: July 28, 2014
												Personally, I love this game. I do agree that originally, it was really short. I was SUPER excited when I found out that they included the mountains of madness... Which I haven't beaten, of course. What scares me about this most of all is the sounds. The constant sound of them and the feel that I don't really know what's going on is awful. There is nothing worst than the sound of a shoggoth somewhere in the level, and you've got no idea where or how many there are. Even worst is when its wife is the shop owne, and you decide to steal. *shudders*The game can be short, sweet, and to the point. This can mean that you've won by being one smart little sh**, or that you died. Repeatedly. It's definitely a roguelike in that when you die... You start all over. So don't die.I question myself whether it's worth its listed price. Right now, with the MOuntains of Madness, I think it is. I wouldn't mind more updates in the future, say, adding more notes and minor references to Lovecraft's works. This could be in secrets, too, and in maybe a couple new weaons. Doesn't have to be fancy; like, a special type of bladed weapon in the sandy level, and so on and so forth.That said, above all else, I do recommend this game- IF you like Lovecraft's works. Otherwise, you may not get it, and it may not be your taste. Lovecraft isn't nearly as dry as Poe was, but he can definitely be dry. This game corporates his type of fear- that you are vastly out-gunned, out-manned, and just out of your league.

Posted: August 21, 2014
												Geniales Game. Sieht zwar aus wie Minecraft, aber außer dem Grafikstil haben die beiden Spiele nichts gemeinsam.Man schleicht durch prozedural generierte Levels in denen alle mögliche Horror Figuren aus den Werken von H.P. Lovecraft lauern und muss sich Ebene um Ebene weiter nach unten kämpfen, mit zunehmend steigendem Schwierigkeitsgrad. Die Grafik ist zwar sehr minimal gehalten aber die Spannung wird hier (wie in vielen Horror-Games) hauptsächlich durch die Audioatmosphäre erzeugt, welche in Eldritch sehr gut gelungen ist.Um sich gegen die zahlreichen Gegner zur Wehr zu setzen gibt es verschiedene Waffen und Powerups, z.B Unsichtbarkeit, stärkere Angriffsstärke usw., die man im Level findet, hin und wieder in Shops kauft oder von getöteten Gegnern lootet, die dadurch aber wieder an einer anderen Stelle im Level spawnen, also sollte man sich öfters überlegen ob es das loot Wert ist, besonders mit niedrigen Leben.Fällt man allerdings doch einem der Gegner oder einer der Fallen zum Opfer, bedeutet das in guter Roguelike Manier Permadeath und man kann ein neu generiertes Level von vorne beginnen und sämtliche vor dem Tod gesammelten Gegenstände gehen dabei verloren.Eldritch ist kein hardcore schweres Spiel, was es für mehr Leute zugänglich macht, aber kann besonders in den fortgeschrittenen Levels doch anspruchsvoll werden. Das, ergänzt von dem sehr guten Sounddesign und prozedural generierte Levels, die theoretisch unendliches Wiederspielen ermöglichen, macht Eldritch zu einer klaren Kaufempfehlung.

Posted: November 4, 2013
												Eldritch combines stealth, survival, and exploration in ways that I have yet to experience in other games. While the normal campaign is rather short and easy, the new game plus mode will put your roguelike skills to the test. I would have preferred having access to this mode from the beginning of the game, but even as is, I would say that this is a great buy for roguelike veterans. While it might not have a deep RPG system or a lengthy item list, destructible environments and some great random level generation make Eldritch a unique experience.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												Surprisingly a good take on Lovecraftian fiction. Many games don't do the genre Lovecraft created very well, the only exception in my book would be 'Dark Corners of the Earth' and the 'Call of Cthulhu' paper and pen RPG. This game isn't 'THEIF' or 'Dark Corners of the Earth' or the next revolution in gaming, but if you are looking for a game to kill time and have a good time, 'Eldritch' is the game to play. Using simplistic rogue styled gameplay, the game is suprisingly well created. The player has the ability to run and slide, look over corners, sneak, and many more. It also has a refreshing play-through, because every dungeon is different. With the additional 'Mountains of Madness' DLC that comes WITH the game, this is, FOR SURE, a great buy.

Posted: March 26
												Eldritch is an FPS, stealth-horror, rogue-lite in which you delve into dungeons full of monsters and traps that you have to deal with using the tools and abilities the game gives you along the way. It features a strong atmosphere that keeps you on your toes; not knowing what might be waiting for you around the corner.This is how the game experience was for me, and I loved it. However, as time went on the game's horror-elements began to peel away as I better understood the mechanics and how easy it was to avoid the enemies in the first place. Find the right gear and know how to cheese the enemies' AI and the game loses that creepy edge it once had.Regardless; the game is still a lot of fun although it doesn't have the same replay-value as other rogue-likes of its kind. However I don't think it really needs to. It lasts just long enough and I don't think it would benefit from being as replayable as something like Spelunky or The Binding of Isaac.It's incredibly simple and incredibly effective, and that's what makes me want to recommend it.PROS:- Simple yet charming graphics.- Strongly atmospheric SFX and ambience.- Fun and interesting gameplay mechanics.- Great gameplay progression.- Lasts just long enough.CONS:- Very little replay value.- Loses its strong atmosphere as you learn the mechanics.SCORE: 9/10

Posted: June 14, 2016
Eldritch is a procedurally-generated FPS dungeon crawler with rougelite and stealth functions built in. The premise of the game is to collect 3 orbs, one per world, and use them to escape the hub area, known as the Library. Each world exists within a book on a pedestal within the Library, and each contain differing enemy types and hazards. Within the Library, 3 extra worlds exist, including the Mountains of Madness, Trick-or-Treat, and the Asylum.Within the game, you can find basic items, such as artifacts, keys, and ammunition. Stonger items include boots, gear, kits, weapons, tools, and much more. You even discover shrines that give you magical abilities. Artifacts act as a form of currency and as fuel for your magic, and can be stored in bank chests to be used in future runs.You begin the game with no items or build at all. You find everything needed within the books to make a build. You can take a stealthy approach, using silent weapons to subdue foes or tossing items to distract them instead. If that doesn't suit you, then try going in guns blazing, shooting anything that moves and blowing through walls. With certain builds, you can even just outrun everything, not really fighting them at all.Death is that of a rougelite, removing all progress that you have made in the worlds. However, artifacts that have been banked and opened books stay unlocked, making death a matter of trying again.The game is really easy to get into, but takes time and dedication to perform well in. With it's high replayability, it shouldn't be too hard to continue trying.


YouTube™ Video: [LP] INTO THE MOUTH OF MADNESS | Eldritch

Posted: September 12, 2015
To The Point Review:+Roguelike+Unique-Mix and Match Tactics +Challenging+Lots Of Play time+DTH Ratio: 0.41$+Great Atmosphere+Strategic+Unique Enemies and AI-At times brutal difficulty-Somewhat repetitive exploration-Surprise EndingFluff Review:Eldritch is a great game with a weird name. Even though this game never explains the origins of its name, it might be linked to the definition of the word: “weird / spooky”. This game certainly is spooky, and unique. The worlds you explore are randomly generated in this 1st person roguelike. The tactics you can employ can be as diverse or simple as you need. You can sneak up on people and stab them from behind for a critical hit, you can shoot from afar, or you can distract your enemies and never face them at all. Personally, I would summon Shaggoths (what look like giant furry heaps of hay painted green with bloody teeth and creepy eyes) and have them lash out at all of my enemies, whether it attacked baby cthulus, wizards, or lizardmen. I am somewhat ashamed to admit that I took a savage pleasure in strolling into a shop, talking to the clerk, and then summoning a mighty shaggoth to murder the clerk while I looted the store. But that is the beauty of the game. You can choose what you do, how you play, and risk your safety. The game is permadeath, so the penalty of getting hurt can be brutal. I played 36 hours before I beat the game, so my Dollar to Hour Ratio was 41 cents for every hour I played the game, which is great. The enemies you face are unique. Different species sometimes fight each other, wizards hate you, and Shaggoths want to kill everyone. Shaggoths are invincible, so I ended up adapting my strategy to locking them up in little huts I encountered. The difficulty can be, at times, brutal. I remember at one point being halfway through the game, and falling into a hole in which I could not get out of, and I was forced to restart my game. Once you play the game a lot, exploring can become repetitive. The end was very much a surprise, and not a good one. I liked where the story was going, but as it reached the climax, you click ‘f’ and the game is done, just like that!Overall, I would give this game a thumbs up.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												I personally would say that this game can be worth the $15 it asks for. Most people talk as if this game is simple and easy to beat. I do not find it to be that simple. The whole goal of the game is to go into a dungeon to get an orb to unlock another dungeon. That's what i've found so far at least. I haven't progressed farther then the second dungeon as I died while playing in it. Upon death you lose all of your items and money (Aside from any money stored in the games "Bank") and can either respawn in the normal library you start in or go into another dungeon that is timed. I tried out this timed dungeon a few times after dying but found it to be a lot harder then the other two dungeons. It throws all the enemies and items into the dungeon with a (rouhgly) two minute time limit to get to the next floor or be consumed by a block smoke of death. This being said, if you do make it through this timed dungeon I assume you get to go back to the library with the items gained and have an advantage over whatever you are facing in the next dungeon. The only problem that a player may encounter in the game while fighting is the amount of health that is givin at the start. You can find health boosts to raise your health from three, but it only does it by one. This adds the difficulty as the only hard enemy in the first dungeon is a blob that you can't kill. The second dungeon however has a ghost of sorts that will hit for two points of health and is infact unkillable as well. (Though however hitting them causes them to "play dead" for a couple seconds) All in all this can add some challenge if, like me, you play the game without the intent of speed running it but instead taking in whatever it has to offer gameplay wise. I couldn't help but feel like a more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ character from Dishonored due to the powers that can be gained along with the dagger that can kill most things in two hits. In short:=The game can offer a more play time then the two hours that most people complain about. I assume they get that result because they bum rush as fast as they can.=The main disadvantage a player will have in the game is the lack of health and the rarity of places to increase health (Though food to heal can be rather abundant)=The varying difficulty in dungeons can be seen rather clearly.=The graphics aren't really anything that bad. Honestly, in this time period people can make games that look anything from the original mario to the latest AAA FPS game and you'll still get someone complaining about the looks of something. So if you don't like the game from the first look of the provided video or photos and already let it spoil the game for you then you probably shouldn't get the game.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												Eldritch is a game that works out a bit however you want it to; what feels like a stellar fusion of ambient horror and rougelike for the slow and cautious can be an entirely different affair for the sort who wants to run in guns a-blazin'.  This results in a game where your experience can be highly personalized, which is far from a bad thing.Eldritch has you taking on the role of a lone Librarian who must delve into sinister realms in their search of escape, dealing with Lovecraftian horrors while salvaging resources and managing whatever hand they're dealt.  The monster variety and what they bring to the table is impressive for the game's scope - one achievement tasks you with finishing the game in under ten minutes, so this is hardly the lengthiest of affairs, though there's a fair degree of difficulty in the obstacles one must overcome here, and that's ignoring the increased challenge of new game+ and newer areas released over time after the game's initial release.And those extended additions are well worth mentioning: the main game sports three worlds and a final challenge to fight your way through, each with its own distinct flavor with regards to traps, archetecture and monster variety.  It's a solid package in and of itself, but the addition of a score-chasing, fast-paced scavenger hunt through the Asylum, the lengthy and absurdly challenging mountain expedition, and a fairly friendly bonus feast of a Halloween realm are all welcome additions, adding to the game's replayability and depth.Eldritch isn't the prettiest thing you'll see by any stretch, but the audio atmosphere is strong, and the player's vulnerability only adds to the tension.  Your decisions as you progress greatly impact your odds of survival, and the obstacles you face are overwhelming in number.  Whether you choose to take your time and soak it all in carefully or run in screaming like a banshee, there's a lot here worth your attention.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Eldritch is as cool as it sounds. It's fun, well-designed, surprisingly atmospheric, and even a bit terrifying at times (there's at least one enemy that will keep you extremely paranoid).My favorite part about the game is the 3D design of the levels. Each floor has multiple "sub-floors" and there are a lot of ways to move between sub-floors. Finding the exit is usually not too difficult, but finding your way to a shop or other area of interest can be surprisingly involved. There are also ways to get around this such as dynamite and pickaxes, which really take advantage of the 3D maze design.While the game itself is a bit short, it can take a good number of attempts to complete it, not counting the extra campaign that can be accessed right from the start. Survival means learning the hazards of each area and how each enemy behaves. There's a lot of challenge to this game, but it ultimately feels fair.There's also a decent amount of extra stuff to go for when you beat the game, such as a harder new game+ mode, a super-tough extra area with a leaderboard, some challenging achievements, and more.As someone who was just getting tired of roguelikes, this game was refreshing and fun.

Posted: May 27, 2015
												A neat little timesink that's shockingly enjoyable and atmospheric considering its texture quality.In the first 3 minutes the game had me transported to a labyrinthian maze, launching and swinging from grappling wires, and getting eaten by Shoggoth.  Eldritch is a sweet little Lovecraftian loveletter in the guise of an FPS puzzler.  The overall structure of the world is hub-based, with a library serving as your home base where you may teleport to various realms in search of supplies, powerups, and monsters to battle.  The levels are sprawling monoliths with varying (and sometimes destructable) terrain; and the soundtrack and effects are genuinely creepy, creating a surprising amount of immersion in a game whose texturing would make Wolfenstein 3D proud.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												I don't really mean to give this a bad review, I just find the game really... meh. We have a Call of Cthulhu themed stealthish RNG rouge-like where you have to pass 12 levels to win the game. First off, I'm a big lovecraft fan and a Call of Cthulhu writer, so I really appreciated the journals left around and I was very interested in the asylum portion of the game, just from a creative standpoint. However, the gameplay leaves a lot to be desired and a lot of that comes from the format of the levels. You go through 3 maps to get souls of various gods. The problem is that every map is basically the same. Sure,  there's an underwater theme, a desert theme, and a davy jones/nautical theme, but in every map, you have one goal, find your way to the exit at the bottom. You have to race to the bottom 3 times per themed area, which means you have to successfully pass 12 maze maps before you can even attempt the finale. With that, its no wonder that only 4.5% of all players who bought this game have actually finished it. Not to mention that to get the best ending, you need to find 3 sacred items that are hidden somewhere within the 12 levels before the finale. Because of the level design, I barely find myself sneaking and instead just race to the bottom as fast as possible it works 66% of the time. Additionally, I found the combat to be too easy 66% of the time, negating the purpose of sneaking all together. Why so specific? The Cthulhu and Dagon themed areas have really easy enemies. Deep Ones, Cultists, and Star-spawn will usually either kill themselves by accident or a knife is enough to kill all the enemies in a level without taking any damage. However, the Nytharlotep area is by far the hardest and can take hours just to get a single good run in. This is because the enemies are really non-standard. One enemy (of which there are many in a single level) is a mummy that can't be killed, only stunned. Another is a lizard statue that teleports to attack you if you stop looking at it. The problem then is that to finish the Nytharlotep area, you have to pass by a hall of lizard statues lined up like terra-cotta warriors. You can't look at them the whole time because the door they're guarding is locked most (if not all) the time and so your only hope is to find enough dynamite in the stage to get rid of them or have enough health points to take the hits. Its really frustrating to reach the bottom and then to die because of this one enemy type that will alwasy be at the end point. Last note: I wish they had put in a different god than Dagon, because we've already seen Deep Ones in a Call of Cthulhu game before. I wish they had done something like Yog-Sothoth or some-such. Anyway, again this isn't a bad review, its just... meh.

Posted: October 23, 2015
												A very twisted and interesting little game. There are a lot of great nods to the Cthulhu mythos, and the game is simple enough to pick up and play and explore. The design does make the game seem Minecraftesque, but the atmosphere will quickly change your perception of this game.The only real short coming of the game is that while it is simple, it may be a bit too limited for gamers looking for current gen thrills. But if you're willing to squeeze out more from this game there is a lot to be had: speedruns, Asylum challenges, New Game+ mode, and the atmosphere means that you will find yourself coming back again and again. If you're into creepiness and Lovecraftian horror, you will play this game. Everyone else, this game is worth giving a try.

Posted: October 14, 2015
												This was a game I almost skimmed over due to its 'Minecraftian' graphics and the general lack of quality in most Lovecraft-themed adaptations. I'm glad I didn't.I was dumped into this game with no idea what was going on, which automatically put me on the defense. As I delved deeper, traversing the game's labyrinthian levels I felt an increasing sense of forboding and terror. The randomized level design really does so much more for this game than just replayability - it embodies the sense of total alienation from what we expect from reality. The bizzare and often functionless twists, turns and passages create an unrelatable setting that is slightly off-putting - even moreso with the knowledge that some unspeakable horror could be lurking just around the corner.The audio is spot on for the more cosmic-oriented arc of Lovecraft's work. Droning saw-wave synths with occasional atmospheric oddities, sounds of doors opening and footsteps, the screechings of some extraterrestial fiend - it all culminates to add to the immersive dread of this title.If you're after a terrifying alien Lovecraftian experience then this title might just scratch your itch.

Posted: October 16, 2015

I hope you read and memorized them, 'cause you're never seeing them again. Certain enemies are kinda bull, like the fire-frog, which you wont see, and which fires too fast and acuratly to melee. The statues suck too, if you wake one up you're basicly already dead.If the developer sees this, please add an option to reset the game. I'd love to see everything it has to offer!

												Ill make it clear. Never Read an H.P Lovecraft book.. but from what I've managed to study about this game and the books theyre based off of The game nails it pretty good, So for fans of Mr Lovecrafts work this game is a must have!Personally this game makes me think of the first Legend of Zelda but in 3d with the ability to grab ledges and climb and change your weapons to even a gun which ammo has to be gathered most of the time.Not a terribly hard game to beat considering if your good you can just get a compass and a pickaxe and finish all three books in under ten minutes as well as the final level after.. I have yet to make a dent in the New game Plus mode though so the replayability is actually unreal for just a small game no ones ever heard about.. I keep coming back due to these factors and all around its actually fun to try to stealth or slay your way through the levels.. though limited to like 6 levels ive found they are procedurally generated and you never get the same game twice.. Well done highly reccomended to anyone not just fans of Lovecraft books =)

Posted: April 7, 2015
												This game is an absolute delight. The first time invokes terror, a terror that, like many games, you eventually dispel as you finally make your way to your first victory, only to return when you're low on health, and hear something around the corner. The moments of fear are gripping, the moments of action thrilling. There is a true lucidity of design here, it feels as though everything is in its place for a reason. I felt satisfaction and anguish in equal measure, stabbing many a cultist in the back only to duck into a narrow crevasse a moment later, waiting for the sounds of a Shoggoth to recede into the distance. My blood has chilled as a monster of stone has spotted me, and I have stalked through R'lyeh, fearful of waking its denizens. Immersive and well worth the price, this game comes highly recommended. Truly a study in maximising minimal resources, from a game designer's perspective. Here I thought I would never encounter pixel-induced terror, but Minor Key Games has proven me wrong.

Posted: October 22, 2013
												A tense-yet-gracious FPS Spelunky-like. Grace may seem hard to find at first. The Lovecraft-inspired world of Eldritch rarely relents in its palpable gloom, and the inherent nature of a roguelike reduces one to survivalist instincts. But by making the end attainable and by opening the game up to a diversity of approaches, Eldritch’s forgiving difficulty means that more than the hardcore elite can overcome the this roguelike’s inherent stress and difficulty, leaving the average player slightly more comfortable with dying to self in the name of progress.Read More: http://gamechurch.com/eldritch-a-gracious-descent/

												I'm not really one for 8-bits indie games to tell you the truth. The graphics at first didn't catch my attention. So, I wasn't planning to buy it. Later it was on sell for around $2 and this game was recommanded by some top curators; I thought, why not?I was thinking to myself that the game was only $2, so I had nothing to lose; bought the game.This game is amazing. I love the eeriness that overwhelms the game; well done developers.The game takes place in a huge library. You "read" a book and you get sucked in into the world/demension. Your task is to keep getting out into you find your way back to the library. Easier said than done.You're always conscience on what you're doing in the game; trying to hear the mosters talking to know how close they are. You can go to the shop, buy or steal and run as fast as you can. And you might even be able to kill the shop owner, go back, and steal everything else.This is by far one of my favorite indie games ever.9/10

Posted: August 27, 2014
												Quick review: Well worth the purchase, spend your money on this product. Longer review: Eldritch is the kind of game a lot of us roguelike fans look for. Each world you enter has 3 levels, each level having 3 layers, which at first doesn't sound like a lot. However each level is made by several randomly generated 'squares' holding random items, enemies and secrets to hunt out. Sometimes the generated parts don't seem to fit in with the squares next to it but considering the lovecraftian theme of the game this really only adds to the bizarre non-euclidean feel to the worlds with each world feeling increasingly dangerous and bizarre. Now a bad part of this game is that if you push through with a speed run it's not hard to finish, however the real charm to this game is taking your time to explore every nook and cranny of the levels you're in. Finding the little secrets and involving yourself in the survival aspect of the game is really what brings out the charm and tension the game has in spades. Lovecraft fans  will get a huge kick out of identifying the various monsters you can slay (or more likely run away from) and even get a laugh out of the shopkeepers that are unique to each world (The veiled lady Shoggoth was my personal favourite). Speaking of shopkeepers the game really has a great mechanic in the form of artifacts, which act as both your source of magic and currency. Do you spend the artifacts you have to get some vital upgrades in the shop, or save them for the unholy powers granted by the Cthulhu statues? Or even put them into your bank, to save in case you die later on? Bullets are also somewhat scarce to come by and sooner or later you WILL find yourself falling back on to stealth to sneak past enemies or risk going up behind them and taking them by surprise. Another great mechanic lies in if you want to loot the fallen foes for possible ammo, keys or artifacts but be warned, looted foes WILL rise again to continue hunting you through the levels. More than once you'll find yourself making the tough choices to risk another battle with a monster just to gamble on getting an extra key or much needed revolver ammo.You could maybe point out the blocky graphics count as a negative but for us born before the year 2000 the graphics only add an old school FPS look to everything, when games would punish you for making mistakes and, trust me, this game will PUNISH YOU for acting cocky or not thinking an action through. Think you're tough because you've got full health and a strong weapon? You'll be cursing blind when something leaps out at you from the shadows and mauls you to death because you weren't checking every corner for fishmen, star-spawn or cultists.If I was to think of anything truly negative I would say the repetitive enemies and the occasionally simplistic AI can take you out the game, especially when you find the block power or find yourself knifing a Elder Spawn to death by strafing around it. It can be very easy to MAKE the game easy if you know what you're doing and finding the high ground early on is a good way to make things easier (until the flying eyes come at you...).In all this game is a fantastic buy and very involving, especially from what I understand is a small two-man stuido. I hope they produce more content for Eldritch in the future. Absolutely recommended!

Posted: January 14, 2014
												To think that I impulse-bought this in the last Steam sale... If I had only known I would enjoy it more than any of the big budget games I had been looking forward to I would have saved my money and bought a bunch of copies of Eldritch instead! If you're looking for a stealth-based, rogue-like with a heavy emphasis on 3D platforming and atmosphere, it doesn't get better than this. Most people look at a few screenshots, write it off as a Minecraft cash-in, and move on. The poor fools! They don't even know what they're missing!One thing is true: the graphics are nothing special. They capture the very minimum of their subject and the surroundings. There are some nice color palettes though, and the blocky nature light is cast makes it very obvious if you can be seen or not. And although the textures are unimpressive, the random level design is just as fun to look at as it is to traverse. Thankfully the audio is spectacular. Echoed moans, gurgles, gasps follow you wherever you go and always make you wonder what's just below your feet. The minimalist soundtrack is just as compelling. Obviously it's not a toe-tapping good time, but it certainly puts you on edge and makes you feel... Well, weird.'Weird' is really the name of the game here. This isn't meant to be made into a reaction compilation on your Let's Play channel. It focuses on the 'Weird Tales' aspect in favor of a more frightening experience. For those of you who have been waiting patiently for a Lovecraftian game to mean more than fishmen and tentacle monsters yelling "Boo!", this won't impress you. Also I'm really sorry and you must be REALLY used to disappointment by now.This kind of highlights the weakest part of Eldritch: Lovecraft's world is alien and incomprehensible, but rogue-likes are inherently games about monotony and understanding. To beat a rogue-like means minimizing risks, self-mastery, and knowledge, but Lovecraft is about inescapable, cosmic realities, where knowledge comes at a VERY high cost and these horrors can never be beat, only kept at bay.Eldritch's greatest strength, the genuinly alien nature of the random levels, the strange monsters that can't always be killed, and the crushing atmosphere instantly undo the game the moment you know how to avoid all the traps and deal with all the monsters. The first playthrough is magical: learning all of the powers, items, weapons, traps, monsters, seeing all of these non-sensical worlds realized... It's all so daunting in a very Lovecraftian way. But when you start farming world 1 for artifacts, or you start gearing up for the harder worlds, it's already too late.If you're someone who knows Lovecraft as that guy with the strange tenticle fetish, or you're someone who can put the Lovecraftian label aside and just take in the very dreary tone and solid rogue-like mechanics, then I'd pick this game up without hesitation. If you've been patiently waiting for the Mythos to finally be realized in a computer game, than you'll have to keep waiting.

Posted: August 21, 2014
												Eldritch is a neat little First Person Action game with procedurally generated levels and a heavily HP Lovecraft themed setting. The player must simply navigat from one end of each stage to the other, fighting off various tentacled, disgusting, gibbering flavors of "Oh god, kill it, kill it, kill it!". Along the way, you find weapons and equipment and meat to aid your trek. The game strikes a good balance of risk versus reward through the gameplay. You can't take many hits without dying and healing gets a bit sparse later on, so caution is a necessity at all times, but without a good amount of excess exploration, you'll quickly run out of supplies. Monsters also drop items and respawn indefinitely, but charging out to kill things is always a bit risky. It helps to set a nice atmosphere that, while you have a lot of power over the obstacles you'll face, it doesn't take many mistakes to see you fail. It's a game that greatly rewards patience and caution, while swiftly punishes recklessness. This balance is highly reminiscent of Spelunky in the best ways. While the difficulty starts out a bit insultingly easy, it quickly ramps up into a perfect sweet spot of hectic tension. The selection of items and spells, however, could use a little work. I never really found myself deviating from the set of items I was using and quickly equipping myself with them each new playthrough. For this type of game, always having access to one's preferred loadout, seems a bit off. As a suggestion, perhaps equipment should wear out over time, forcing the player to make do with what they can scrounge up, which seems more suited to this type of game. As for the spells, I think there just need to be more that can compete with the utility of Materialize. I mean, come on. The musis is good, and doesn't interfere with the profoundly important cocktails of squaks and hisses emanating from potential nearby threats. The graphics are, well, modest. It's not exactly going to push the limits of anyone's system , but you can tell right away what everything is supposed to be. Well, not the monsters, but that's  not really because of the graphics. One complaint I have to make is that the particle effects have an annoying linger about them, especially the one coming from the player's left hand at all times. I frequently found myself jumping, thinking I had seen something out of the corner of my eye, only to realize it was an errant particle from the trail I was leaving, which was a tad irritating. On the whole, there isn't really much content here, but what there is is very well made and fun to play. I highly recommend this game to people who enjoy Spelunky and other similar games.

												Geniales Game. Sieht zwar aus wie Minecraft, aber außer dem Grafikstil haben die beiden Spiele nichts gemeinsam.Man schleicht durch prozedural generierte Levels in denen alle mögliche Horror Figuren aus den Werken von H.P. Lovecraft lauern und muss sich Ebene um Ebene weiter nach unten kämpfen, mit zunehmend steigendem Schwierigkeitsgrad. Die Grafik ist zwar sehr minimal gehalten aber die Spannung wird hier (wie in vielen Horror-Games) hauptsächlich durch die Audioatmosphäre erzeugt, welche in Eldritch sehr gut gelungen ist.Um sich gegen die zahlreichen Gegner zur Wehr zu setzen gibt es verschiedene Waffen und Powerups, z.B Unsichtbarkeit, stärkere Angriffsstärke usw., die man im Level findet, hin und wieder in Shops kauft oder von getöteten Gegnern lootet, die dadurch aber wieder an einer anderen Stelle im Level spawnen, also sollte man sich öfters überlegen ob es das loot Wert ist, besonders mit niedrigen Leben.Fällt man allerdings doch einem der Gegner oder einer der Fallen zum Opfer, bedeutet das in guter Roguelike Manier Permadeath und man kann ein neu generiertes Level von vorne beginnen und sämtliche vor dem Tod gesammelten Gegenstände gehen dabei verloren.Eldritch ist kein hardcore schweres Spiel, was es für mehr Leute zugänglich macht, aber kann besonders in den fortgeschrittenen Levels doch anspruchsvoll werden. Das, ergänzt von dem sehr guten Sounddesign und prozedural generierte Levels, die theoretisch unendliches Wiederspielen ermöglichen, macht Eldritch zu einer klaren Kaufempfehlung.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												I love Eldritch but the funny thing about it is that I was at first disappointed (I initially thought there would be more backstory/adventuring involved, but I had little understanding of the type of game it was at the time, so that’s on me and in no way should it throw anyone off from enjoying it!).  It’s only after putting 12+ hours into it that I now realize how great it is as far as rogue-likes are concerned.  Sure, there’s perma-death but you’ll keep the cash-monies you had in your bank chest upon resurrecting/exiting then restarting.  Also, if you’re new to this game the Mountains of Madness, Asylum and Halloween/Pumpkin additions were added after its release, for free!  There’s a good bit of strategy involved if you wish to beat the 3 missions (MoM, Asylum and of course the library the game takes place in).  Pickaxes, dynamite and even a charm that gives the gun the ability to fire bullets that break the environment (all of which do it Minecraft-style) can be utilized to your advantage.  You can even pick up different kinds of packs,  like the med pack that can revive you upon death as long as you have 50 gem thingies (‘artifacts’ as the game puts it) to spend, and boots that can grant different abilities, like high jumping and speed. Be warned, though the enemies may look ‘cute-ish’, they can be, and often are, downright deadly!  And In keeping with the lore of Lovecraft and the retro/blocky graphics, the enemies look great in that classic, cheesy 50’s era way.   On a final note, though Eldritch is certainly humorous at times, it’s still a horror game at its core and it certainly does justice to the godfather of modern sci-fi/horror, the man and legend that started it all, H.P. Lovecraft --- R.I.P. good sir, you live on through us all!!

Posted: December 9, 2014
												TL;DR - This game's definitely worth playing, but not necessarily beating, depending on how much time you can put into it. How-Rogue-like-you-like-it?For what it's worth, I'd say this is more of a horror game that uses elements like procedural generation, permadeath and the inability to save to enhance the experience rather than a true Rogue-like (or Rogue-lite) game. Elements such as the changes to the level layout and item locations each time you play it, as well as excellent sound design on the echoing cries of enemies and some nice touches in the art style (specifically how the subtle bulges on the walls warp the straight lines on them as the camera moves, making them seem to 'writhe') help build a sense of unease and dread as you creep around. As a Lovecraft fan I was delighted by recognizing the different creatures as enemies and appreciated the theming of the level around its elder being (the dry colours of Nyarlathotep, the 'wetness' of Dagon etc), though they're interesting enough that they wouldn't be lost on someone more casually aware of the mythos.This all makes the game worth playing (at least, I think so), but is it worth beating? I mentioned the permadeath, and that will be the big 'make or break' for many players. In order to beat this game you have to finish all three of the 'main' stages (more have been added in patches since release, but I don't believe they count) AND the final level, all on one life. You can save and quit to pick up on where you left off, and deposit money you find in certain places for later that carries over, but you start from the beginning with nothing upon death. For example the furthest I got was beating the Dagon stage and half of Nyarlathotep before I died, and upon respawning my having won Dagon was undone. For those unfamiliar with Rogue-likes this may be a table-flipping moment; for those who know the score, that's part of the thrill. This means however that in order to beat the game you'll have to keep playing over and over until the circumstances to achieve it are just right (or "the stars are correctly alligned", if you will) or to have played so much of the game that you've memorized all the enemy and boss behaviours and all the possible hazards AND don't get screwed by the RNG. This is further reinforced with the Steam Achievements the game offers - beat the game in under 10 minutes, beat it without taking any damage, collect 9,999 coins etc. One can hardly blame a developer for wanting players to play a lot of their game, but for some this may be more time than they can put in.For the Lovecraft fan who's less inclined towards this genre it's still worth giving a go if it's on sale for the ambience and tension of the first few attempts, but if you're seriously inclined towards Roguelikes, or are a Completionist, take a look at some of the other reviews on here to see what the game's long-term prospects are. I liked it, I'll keep playing it, but I doubt I'll beat the entire thing.

This can mean that you've won by being one smart little sh**, or that you died. Repeatedly. It's definitely a roguelike in that when you die... You start all over. So don't die.I question myself whether it's worth its listed price. Right now, with the MOuntains of Madness, I think it is. I wouldn't mind more updates in the future, say, adding more notes and minor references to Lovecraft's works. This could be in secrets, too, and in maybe a couple new weaons. Doesn't have to be fancy; like, a special type of bladed weapon in the sandy level, and so on and so forth.That said, above all else, I do recommend this game- IF you like Lovecraft's works. Otherwise, you may not get it, and it may not be your taste. Lovecraft isn't nearly as dry as Poe was, but he can definitely be dry. This game corporates his type of fear- that you are vastly out-gunned, out-manned, and just out of your league.

												Let's start by getting this out of the way: yes, this looks like a Minecraft mod.  Is it?  Could be, I don't know.  But it doesn't play like one, and that's what's important to me.  Eldrich is a game about dying.  Explore 5 Lovecraftan levels full of horrifying creatures and less ammo than you need.  It does a pretty good job of balancing giving you the power to fight back, but still feeling terrified when you see certain enemies.My biggest criticism is that it's a bit Euclidian for  a Lovecraft game.  But it's a nice, simple survival game with some scary monsters, and technically a plot.  Multiple endings, even, if you can get that far.This isn't the greatest game ever, but if you can get it for a few bucks, or in a bundle, you can definitely have  a lot of fun with it.

Posted: December 9, 2014
												TL;DR - This game's definitely worth playing, but not necessarily beating, depending on how much time you can put into it. How-Rogue-like-you-like-it?For what it's worth, I'd say this is more of a horror game that uses elements like procedural generation, permadeath and the inability to save to enhance the experience rather than a true Rogue-like (or Rogue-lite) game. Elements such as the changes to the level layout and item locations each time you play it, as well as excellent sound design on the echoing cries of enemies and some nice touches in the art style (specifically how the subtle bulges on the walls warp the straight lines on them as the camera moves, making them seem to 'writhe') help build a sense of unease and dread as you creep around. As a Lovecraft fan I was delighted by recognizing the different creatures as enemies and appreciated the theming of the level around its elder being (the dry colours of Nyarlathotep, the 'wetness' of Dagon etc), though they're interesting enough that they wouldn't be lost on someone more casually aware of the mythos.This all makes the game worth playing (at least, I think so), but is it worth beating? I mentioned the permadeath, and that will be the big 'make or break' for many players. In order to beat this game you have to finish all three of the 'main' stages (more have been added in patches since release, but I don't believe they count) AND the final level, all on one life. You can save and quit to pick up on where you left off, and deposit money you find in certain places for later that carries over, but you start from the beginning with nothing upon death. For example the furthest I got was beating the Dagon stage and half of Nyarlathotep before I died, and upon respawning my having won Dagon was undone. For those unfamiliar with Rogue-likes this may be a table-flipping moment; for those who know the score, that's part of the thrill. This means however that in order to beat the game you'll have to keep playing over and over until the circumstances to achieve it are just right (or "the stars are correctly alligned", if you will) or to have played so much of the game that you've memorized all the enemy and boss behaviours and all the possible hazards AND don't get screwed by the RNG. This is further reinforced with the Steam Achievements the game offers - beat the game in under 10 minutes, beat it without taking any damage, collect 9,999 coins etc. One can hardly blame a developer for wanting players to play a lot of their game, but for some this may be more time than they can put in.For the Lovecraft fan who's less inclined towards this genre it's still worth giving a go if it's on sale for the ambience and tension of the first few attempts, but if you're seriously inclined towards Roguelikes, or are a Completionist, take a look at some of the other reviews on here to see what the game's long-term prospects are. I liked it, I'll keep playing it, but I doubt I'll beat the entire thing.

Posted: December 15, 2014
												First, the positives: Eldritch is probably one of the best games that takes advantage of randomly generated maps, particularly 3D ones.  Even though the graphics were simple, the game seemed to "intelligently" position most things, except for wooden doors - some of those seemed very weirdly placed.  The game also does a great job at giving a creepy feel.  For anyone who likes roguelikes, this is a good game.  However, I find having to start from the beginning after making a few stupid mistakes to be annoying.  Thankfully, the game saves your progress to the hard drive, and I just copy+pasted my save so I could continue where I left off.  That being said, I completed the game probably a lot sooner than I should have, and what I did was technically cheating.Now for the negatives: Like I said, being unable to save is irritating, but not something I fault the developers for since it is intentional.  For a game that has well-written books in it, you don't have a strong idea of what you're doing and why you're doing it.  The game gives you very little incentive to explore.  Once you pick up a knife and a revolver, just keep finding health fountains and run straight for the exit.  I have found little to no use to any of the magical spells (though, I'd probably use the teleporter or cloak more often if I didn't "cheat" with saving).  The compass and silent boots are also far more useful than any other item you can pick up.  The items just aren't balanced at all.  I also don't like that once you beat the game, you can't continue where you left off at the library.There's also the obvious "the graphics look bad" complaint.  You get used to it pretty quickly, but I think what bothers me is there's no need for the style.  Aside from the blockiness, the game is actually very detailed in many ways.  The developers easily could have spent a little more time just polishing the appearance of the game - increase polygon count and just do a "cartoony" style instead of the stereotypical indie "8-bit" style.  I understand that using blocks for the floors and walls was needed in order to easily manage functional 3D randomness (and destructable walls), but they could have still kept the cubes and make everything else prettier.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												I'm going to give this game a thumbs up because I think it's interesting and original and I want to show some support for it. After putting several hours in to it, I have to say, it feels somehow incomplete. It's also fairly difficult. The combination of these two things make for diminishing returns. I read a review of this game that described it as a 3D roguelike based on cthulu mythos. It also resembles Minecraft visually but doesn't have the same level of depth or complexity. I like the art style and was thrilled to see lovecraft monsters in chunky 3D. Initially there were some moments where there was a lot of tension in trying to creep around and find items... after a while though, it feels like the possibilities are exhausted. What I like about rogulikes are the randomness and the variety. There are always surprises and you might die in horrible ways but there is also a sense of progression. You 'level up' or find something unusual or rare and it makes the difficulty a little more bearable... you want to jump in and try again. After clearing a couple of maps in eldritch it didn't feel like things were progressing in a way that was engaging for me. I like the idea that you're a lone person and you're scrambling for a few scarce rescources against cthulus minions in strange alien environments, I like the visual style and a lot of the gameplay... it just feels like there's something missing (maybe a few things), that would make me want to keep coming back to the game. I would really like to see some mod support.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												As a huge fan of H.P. Lovecraft and a moderate fan of videogames, I've been dissapointed to not be able to find any decent mythos-related games (aside from Quake, if you count that). ...until now.Eldritch is a wonderful game that combines the feel of Quake with the look of Minecraft and the Cthulhu mythos in a way that's much better than it sounds. It's got this great atmosphere, well-generated dungeons, cute graphics, and has everything a mythos fan like myself could ask for. My favorite part so far has been the echo of one of the bog men in another part of the cave. Despite the voicework making me grin (it's quite funny), it still gives you a feeling of dread, because you know that there's still an enemy somewhere out there...

Posted: October 22, 2013
												A tense-yet-gracious FPS Spelunky-like. Grace may seem hard to find at first. The Lovecraft-inspired world of Eldritch rarely relents in its palpable gloom, and the inherent nature of a roguelike reduces one to survivalist instincts. But by making the end attainable and by opening the game up to a diversity of approaches, Eldritch’s forgiving difficulty means that more than the hardcore elite can overcome the this roguelike’s inherent stress and difficulty, leaving the average player slightly more comfortable with dying to self in the name of progress.Read More: http://gamechurch.com/eldritch-a-gracious-descent/

												Nothing quite beats the fun and joy of running in to a Shogoth, and getting in to a fist fight with it. Needless to say, I didn't quite make it. The game is quite enjoyable, a generally dark atmosphere with a bit of light comedy. The randomly generated dungeons are sure to keep things interesting. Posted: January 2, 2016
												When I saw the trailer I though, Another Voxel, Minecraft-Like spin off but I was wrong, this game is a dungeon crawler randomly generated with not scary, but unfomfortable atmosphere filled with monsters and abominations. It has destructible enviroment and simple stealth mechanics that could be used to avoid or kill enemies. It's challenging ill give it that, but it's often frustrating because if you die you lose everything that is not stored in a bank. A mod support would be really nice.

Posted: January 1, 2016
												I definately recommend this game...while it's on sale!Honestly I wouldn't have touched this game at it's original $15 dollar asking price. But while it's on sale, everyone should pick this game up.Eldritch really ain't half bad. A basic rogue-like but it is very fun to play. Though I learned quickly that the knife and gun are the best weapons and I basically ignore everything else unless I'm desperate or curious. Cloaking and Teleport is also good, but you're never guaranteed those powers.I only use the gun on enemies that can fire projectiles or are hard to kill with the knife (I learned the hard way that Shaggoth is unkillable). But anyway, there is just enough variety to let you experiment with your play style and how you want to go about traversing the levels. Sometimes I try to rocket past every enemy and just make it to the exit, other times I play around and kill every monster in an area. (The ones that can be killed at least) But just remember that when you loot a dead enemy, they respawn later on.The levels don't seem very hard to navigate though, at least as long as you have a compass. And so far it seems that as long as you head downwards, you are going the right way. The shops have good items, especially a pair of boots that silence your footsteps. It's pretty cool.  That's basically how I rate this game. Pretty cool.

Posted: March 26
												Eldritch is an FPS, stealth-horror, rogue-lite in which you delve into dungeons full of monsters and traps that you have to deal with using the tools and abilities the game gives you along the way. It features a strong atmosphere that keeps you on your toes; not knowing what might be waiting for you around the corner.This is how the game experience was for me, and I loved it. However, as time went on the game's horror-elements began to peel away as I better understood the mechanics and how easy it was to avoid the enemies in the first place. Find the right gear and know how to cheese the enemies' AI and the game loses that creepy edge it once had.Regardless; the game is still a lot of fun although it doesn't have the same replay-value as other rogue-likes of its kind. However I don't think it really needs to. It lasts just long enough and I don't think it would benefit from being as replayable as something like Spelunky or The Binding of Isaac.It's incredibly simple and incredibly effective, and that's what makes me want to recommend it.PROS:- Simple yet charming graphics.- Strongly atmospheric SFX and ambience.- Fun and interesting gameplay mechanics.- Great gameplay progression.- Lasts just long enough.CONS:- Very little replay value.- Loses its strong atmosphere as you learn the mechanics.SCORE: 9/10

Posted: December 28, 2015
												This game is enormous fun. It's kind of a fresh game -- the low quality graphics contrasts wonderfully with the creepy sound design, and it's unabashedly a game. It's short too, which I like -- expect to beat it in a couple hours and feel satisfied.I did jump at times (the monsters are creepy!) when a moving statue got me, or a monster followed me into a room.Here's hoping for an Eldritch 2!

Posted: December 29, 2015
												There are five six 'books' or stages, in this game. The first four (three + one) are for the normal game, the fifth is the 'Mountains of Madness' mentioned in the store page video, and the sixth is a place called the 'Asylum' [There is also a Halloween-themed bonus stage, wonder if you can find it. Great for farming artifacts]You have four things on the upper left: Hearts represents health, Blue oval-shapes represent 'artifacts,' or the in-game currency, Green Keys are for unlocking doors, and Yellow Bullets are ammo for your revolver (no reload system, simply M1 until you run out)There is a lot of holding 'shift' in this game (to run), especially for some of the achivements. Unfortunately, there is no toggle to run, unlike for crouching, but not really a big deal.It is not a terribly difficult game. Enemies' projectiles miss often, especially when you are running, and circle strafing enemies while punching/knifing them will dispatch them quickly. For first-time players I would suggest a more cautious approach; my first complete run took about 1 hour 30 minutes.After the inital novelty wears off, there is not much left except the same repeat of: evade/kill enemies, pick up items, move on to the next chapter. For that reason alone, I would not recommend at full price unless you enjoy this genre and/or the Lovecraftian theme. I am not familiar with the universe of H.P. Lovecraft, so I cannot comment on this game's accuracy to its source of inspirationThe redeeming factors that gives life and replayability to this game are the online leaderboards and steam achivements. For those who embrace challenge and enjoy testing their limits, perhaps this game is for you

Posted: December 26, 2015
												A retro-styled 3d rogue-lite set in a twisted cthulhu-esque world.You´re a female or male pulp hero set out to gather the souls of the old ones.You´re doing so by reading ancient tomes in order to teleport to foreign planets and distant dimensions.Or you can grind the mountains of madness or a halloween world.You encounter fish-like frogs or frog-like fishes or star spawns or cultists or shoggoths and the like.Then you´ll bury them one after another, collecting artifacts and ammo or spells to bury them even faster.Except for the shoggoth-things. Those beasts can´t be killed. Or is it a dark young? I can´t tell anymore.Then you casually walk to the 'Ye olde Mythos-Store' to buy or steal even more fancy loot and start all over.Be careful not to catch the shopkeep´s attention when stealing - he´s one tough mothfer....Anyways. Good fun.

												This game is a wildly addicting trip through Lovecraft madness, if you like Rouge-likes and dont have ELDRITCH, what are you doing? go buy it! You can kill Fishmen, cultist, and other Eldritch horrors. If thats not enjoyable then i dont know wwhat is.

Posted: December 28, 2015
												Infinite random dungeons....... one of the few games out there with them and its 3d but sadly it is a little lacking in the content you have a small selection of weapons maybe 5 and can only get 5 spells or so as well. but you can freely destroy the environment with tnt or a pickaxe allowing for shortcuts so overall 9/10 for replayability if you like random dungeons

Posted: July 20, 2016
												At the time of writing this I have unlocked the third book.This game is...well...H.P. Lovecraft certainly rolls in his grave over it.The enemies are scary...at first. After playing about a minute on a floor you get so used to them you're willing to run around and stab everything without any kind of fear. The only real enemies I ran across that stayed a danger were 'unkillable'-The Shoggoth and the Statues. The Statues act like carbon-copy Weeping Angels (which is scary, sure, but they don't activate unless you walk in front of them) and the Shoggoth is...just...It's a giant slime thing that can't be killed. Trap it in a hole and boom, safe.TL;DR:Pros:  - Enemies start off scary and dangerous  - Minimal issues with gathering resources  - Stealth actually WORKS.Cons:  - Enemies quickly become repetitive and boring.  - Resources can be very scarce or be overabundant between floors.  - Stealth is really, REALLY pointless when enemies start gaining flight.  - Dagger too OP.

Posted: October 17, 2016
												Wasn't really sure what to expect when I turned the game on for the first time; but this one was pretty interesting.  It definitely has some Minecraft vibes to it, but this game not at all as forgiving as that game - And if you go in thinking otherwise you'll quickly regret it.  The Cthulhu vibe is definitely here, and I only wish I had survived long enough to enjoy it a bit more.If I had a complaint, it would be the lack of music, but in all honestly the game is still very much worth a look!  Give it a try for yourself, or check out my video below!  OR BOTH!


YouTube™ Video: Eldritch -1- Lovecraftian Blockhead 

			Views: 22		

			Let's look at this interesting adventure/FPS game inspired by H.P. Lovecraft, and roguelikes! Official Website: http://www.eldritchgame.com/ Outro: "AngloZulu" by Kevin Macleod...

Posted: August 22, 2016
												Eldritch is charming, atmospheric and challenging. The rogue-like elements fit well with Loveraft's themes of the unknowable. The blocky representations and sounds of the monsters manage to instill uneasiness at best and panic at worst. There's not a huge variety of weapons, but using certain powerups/gear can offer lots of different strategies for reaching the end of each dungeon. The lack of carry-capacity (only 2 items and one piece of gear per slot) can be frustrating but it allows for experimentation. Once you've memorized the strategies and enemy types, you can fairly easily master the game, and it now comes with a number of expansions that can provide very good entertainment for the price. Highly recommend, especially for Lovecraft fans.

												This game is quite good, particluarly for the price.  Its a solid rouge-like faithful to the classic mechanics such as permadeath.  The biggest complain is that the balancing isnt the best.   StarSpawn are too weak, Lizzard Statues are too stong, and the first chapter is far too easy.  As a resault, the first area is boringly easy, but the second is a massive, intense difficulty spike.  Dispite this flaw, the game is great, and later on can get very tense and exciting.10/10 would get killed by lizard statue on final floor with all relecs again.Seriously though.  I hope all lizard statues die in a fire.

Posted: December 9, 2016
												Extremely fun game, a rouge-like with simple, yet compelling gameplay. Runs fairly well on low-end machines too. The only real problem is that there will be an occassional dungeon which is impossible to complete without some ability to destroy blocks, which is not always possible, but this happens extremely rarely.Another problem is that the achievement statistics do not show up at all, although this is more of valve being dumb than the developer's fault.Otherwise, this game's controls are extremely smooth and responsive, making movement extremely fluid. The graphics are on the low end, but that only adds to the aesthetic in my opinion. I also love the lovecraftian theme, so I may be heavily biased towards this game, but I don't really care because I really enjoyed it. It's well worth the money.

Posted: March 9, 2014
												Eldritch is a lovely title. Seriously. If you melted your computer while running it, it would probably result in a pool of liquid gold... (actually, don't try that.) I love this game. I've played many roguelikes before, so this game was a bit simple to start with, but after your first playthrough, a feature titled New Game+ allows you to amp up the dificulty to where it should be (at least for a roguelike). The game is essentially Dishonored developed by Mojang, allowing you to slide, mantle, and sprint from a first person prospective, rendered in a cute, voxel-based engine. Buy this game if you like Dishonored. Buy this game if you like roguelikes. Screw it, just buy this game becuase it's quality.

Posted: December 9, 2016
												Extremely fun game, a rouge-like with simple, yet compelling gameplay. Runs fairly well on low-end machines too. The only real problem is that there will be an occassional dungeon which is impossible to complete without some ability to destroy blocks, which is not always possible, but this happens extremely rarely.Another problem is that the achievement statistics do not show up at all, although this is more of valve being dumb than the developer's fault.Otherwise, this game's controls are extremely smooth and responsive, making movement extremely fluid. The graphics are on the low end, but that only adds to the aesthetic in my opinion. I also love the lovecraftian theme, so I may be heavily biased towards this game, but I don't really care because I really enjoyed it. It's well worth the money.

												Eldritch is a great game that you're a woman that need to take three orbs in three different scenarios. You start in a library (that is the main map) and from here you will entering in the other areas. Eldritch is a roguelike 3d game, and it's much interesting because for me, I never saw a game roguelike in 3d that you have a objective.

Posted: February 3
												Fun Quirky type of game with minecraft inspired graphics, controls are easy. Comat is slightly spammy but i guess that what you get from a hack and slash type of game. This game has really high replay value, basically you go inside these books and it's like a portal to a certain area and in that specific area you can get these orbs and you need to get a specific number of orbs to open  the main door. I am not that far into the game but i have retrieved one of the orbs and let me tell you there is a lot of trial and error and lastly there are these giant sludge type monsters that are a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥avoid them at all costs you cannot kill them. 7/10

												First world was a peice of cake and gave me this secured feeling of success. The world afetr that however quickly took that feeling of comfort and squashed it like... like something that is easy to squash. In the end it's a great game and it totally was worth the fifteen bucks.

Posted: January 14
												This is one of my favorite game to just mindless play for hours. It doesn't matter how much I play this game, it never loses it's replay value. If you are a fan of dungeon exploration based games, you are going to love this. The good thing is, you can play for this game for short sessions or for hours on end and not get lost on what you need to do.

Posted: April 11
												Not worth the $15 price tag, I got this on sale for $3 and it very much feels like an unfinished mess, the fact you respawn so easily with no real negative reprecussion other than losing your inventory ruins the horror motif, the monsters are scripted in mundane ways that dont give you the variety or spice needed to keep you interested for more than maybe a few minutes, I got bored of this game  in about an hour before dropping play on it entirely
